article_title: Should You Track Your Child?
normalized_article_title: should you track your child
text_content:
New devices that track children’s whereabouts have some people worrying about what happens when children are monitored at all times — and their introduction comes at a time when our society’s attitudes toward supervision are already being hotly debated. What does a standard of constant surveillance mean for kids, many are asking, and for their families?
The electronics company LG recently announced its development of KizON, a wristband for kids that will let their parents track them remotely. The device isn’t available in Europe or the United States yet, but it has already prompted privacy worries. At Wired UK, Liat Clark writes:
“It feels as though KizON is a beginner’s anti-privacy tool, training the next generation to forget about all this NSA nonsense and get on with living life as something of an open book. Today, we have become used to conversations focusing on the implications of living in a post-privacy world. KizON’s existence suggests we have totally given up on the idea that we can reclaim that sense of privacy and autonomy.”
She also worries the device panders to parents’ less than admirable instincts: “The uncomfortable thing is this is squarely aimed at parents, whose paranoia the device’s very existence plays on.” She adds, “If the worst happened, and the kid did go missing or was taken, surely we may as well go all the way and just implant them with a tracker chip. It’s the only way to be sure we know where they are at all times.”
In The Guardian, Rory Carroll expresses similar concerns about tracking technology in development at Cisco. He describes a scenario in which a child’s every move can be closely monitored: “As they ride on the bus Foster’s phone and a sensor on a wristband alert the school and his parents of a deviation from his normal route. The school has been notified that he is heading to Aiden’s house so the police are not called.” And, he writes:
“What sort of childhood is it with every move tracked, scrutinised, logged, judged? Where you cannot wander, try something new, be spontaneous – be yourself – without issuing a beeping alert from wearable, connected technology? This is helicopter parenting at its most stultifying, a constant, hovering presence.”
On Twitter, the Wall Street Journal tech columnist Christopher Mims poses another question: “Will mainstreaming of always-on child trackers make us more or less permissive with our own and others’ children?”
Indeed, recent news has thrown the issue of child supervision — how closely kids need to be watched, and what happens when authorities decide they haven’t been watched closely enough — into high relief. Mr. Mims also points to the case of Debra Harrell, a South Carolina mom who was jailed for leaving her nine-year-old daughter in a park while she went to work.
At The Atlantic, Conor Friedersdorf questions the idea that letting a nine-year-old play at the park alone is dangerous:
“Parents ought to enjoy broad latitude in bringing up their children. There are obviously limits. The state ought to intervene if a child is being abused. But letting a 9-year-old go to the park alone doesn’t come close to meeting that threshold.”
Jessica Grose offers a similar argument at Slate:
“It should be normalized for children who are nearing the end of elementary school to begin doing some things on their own. If every parent who let their fourth-graders go to the park unsupervised were arrested, all the moms from 1972 would have been behind bars.”
And, she adds, the case has disturbing implications for parents: “How can I appropriately parent my child when doing something that seems relatively safe, if out of fashion, can get you arrested?”
As Stacia L. Brown points out on her blog, this risk of arrest may be magnified by racial bias:
“Cases like Debra Harrell’s frighten me. They reify the idea that the rules are different for my black family. For us, noisy nighttime play or unsupervised daytime play don’t just draw annoyance or concern. They draw authorities. They draw teams of people with the power to determine whether or not our children can come home.”
And, she asks:
“At what point does incurious observation become concern? At what point should concern involve intervention? And once authorities have intervened, which infractions should warrant the removal of children from their homes?”
The advent of child tracking devices raises some related questions. Mr. Mims asks how they will affect our treatment of children — but what about our treatment of parents? Will we judge those who don’t track their children? Will we incarcerate them? Will letting kids leave the house without their trackers become the new equivalent of letting them play unsupervised at the park: something that was once acceptable but that we now deem criminally negligent?
And how will our existing biases play into these new norms? Kati Sipp, a writer and union organizer, hints at this last question in her response to Mr. Mims’s tweet. Of child tracking technology, she asks, “Will it allow us to maintain our class prejudices?” Neither she nor Mr. Mims seems optimistic that the new devices would somehow erase these prejudices. And as they make their way to market, these devices may serve as a reminder that our society’s attitudes toward caring for children may be informed not just by our best impulses, but by our worst ones.

article_title: The Gun Report: April 9, 2014
normalized_article_title: the gun report: april 9, 2014
text_content:
Last week, Nathan Trapuzzano, a 24-year-old software engineer and newlywed with a baby on the way, went out for an early morning walk in his Indianapolis neighborhood. He was approached by two people who attempted to rob him, surveillance video shows. One of the would-be thieves pulled out a handgun and shot him in the stomach, killing him.
The story has garnered national attention because of the random nature of the crime, the victim’s age and the fact that he had a baby on the way. “This is a safe city, and that’s why this murder is particularly troubling,” one of the city’s district police commanders said. But six people were shot and killed in Indianapolis that week, drawing attention to a serious problem: Its murder rate eclipses Chicago’s, and most of those killings are perpetrated with firearms.
Last year there were 140 murders in Indianapolis, which has a population of 844,220. This is 10 percent more homicides per capita than Chicago. So far this year, 41 people have been murdered, compared to 32 at this time in 2013—a 28 percent increase. What’s happening in Indy?
The city is a manufacturing, trading and health care hub, but 381 street gangs operate within its borders, and police presence has not kept up with the pace of growth. “You can’t grow to be this big, world class city and don’t grow your public safety to keep up with it,” Joe Wynns, a former city park director, told ABC 6 last year. “You’ll become a murder capital of the world.” Only 1,500 police officers patrol the city, and “we can’t be everywhere all the time,” Lt. Chris Bailey of the Indianapolis Metropolitan police said at a crime-prevention meeting last night.
With the uptick in gun violence in recent years, community and church groups have picked up the slack, patrolling the streets and engaging with youth. Educators say kids as young as 12, many of whom come from strong middle-class homes, are joining criminal enterprises for money, protection and prestige.
One of those kids, 16-year-old Simeon Adams, is the prime suspect in Nathan Trapuzzano’s murder. When police caught up with him, he was hospitalized with a gunshot wound to the neck he received only hours after Trapuzzano’s killing. Adams is also wanted for shooting another man two days before that.
“Oh how my already wounded heart aches to hear this,” Jennifer Trapuzzano posted on Facebook. “Nate always said one of the greatest crimes in the world today is how many babies grow up without their father. I don’t know this man’s circumstances but it hurts to hear that such a young man could turn to such violence. Please pray for his conversion.”
Here is today’s report.
—Jennifer Mascia
A Marine at Camp Lejeune in North Carolina was shot and killed by another Marine Tuesday afternoon. The suspect was standing guard at the camp’s main gate when he turned his M4 rifle on a Marine who was also acting as a guard. The shooting is being investigated by the Naval Criminal Investigative Service.
Yvonne Treslar, 78, was shot and killed at her home in Monkton, Md., Monday afternoon, and her husband, 82-year-old Glen Treslar, was arrested. Treslar confessed to shooting his wife and told police they had argued earlier, but he did not explain why he shot and killed the family dog.
—WTOP
Karen Johnson, 41, was killed in a domestic shooting at her home in Shreveport, La., Monday night. The victim was found lying under the carport of the home. Anton C. Cooley, 41, was arrested.
Toryion Conner, 15, who was disabled from gunshot wounds he sustained in Chicago in 2012, died Sunday. He had been walking home from a party with friends when someone opened fire on the group, striking him in his spinal cord, chest and hand and relegating him to a wheelchair. In recent years he didn’t want to leave the house, and became further agitated by his older brother’s shooting last year. Conner’s mother found him unresponsive in their home. “He just didn’t have the fight in him anymore,” she said.
Rashawn Franklin, 19, and a 15-year-old were shot and wounded in Kinston, N.C., Tuesday afternoon.
Darnell Carden was wounded in the chest when someone opened fire on a home he was visiting in east Charlotte, N.C., late Monday. Four adults, a 4-year-old, a 6-year-old and a baby were home at the time. “What is it going to take for this to stop, the violence?” his mother asked. Police have not revealed a motive.
A 24-year-old man was shot in the chest during an argument inside a nightclub on Chicago’s Goose Island early Tuesday. No suspects are in custody. That afternoon in Chicago, a 24-year-old man was shot in the Auburn Gresham neighborhood.
Christopher Carter, 23, was wounded and Carmen Caldwell, 31, was critically wounded and when someone opened fire on their car at a gas station in Indianapolis, Ind., early Tuesday. Detectives do not know the motive behind the attack and no one has been arrested.
Babul Kumer Saha, 41, a clerk at a gas station convenience store, was shot in the head at close range and killed during a robbery in Maple Heights, Ohio, late Monday. The suspect was captured on surveillance video and police are searching for him. The victim had moved here from Bangladesh less than two years ago, and he leaves behind a wife and two children under the age of four.
Antonio Counts, 28, was killed, and Donald Hill, 34, was wounded in a shooting in North Augusta, S.C., early Tuesday. The victims were found in a car resting in a ditch.
—WJBF
Patricia Kinkade-Dorsey, 64, was shot to death in a house in Oakland, Iowa, early Tuesday. The homeowner, 63-year-old Robert A. Reynolds Jr., who as a friend of the victim, was arrested. Reynolds’s wife, his 17-year-old stepdaughter and a grandchild were home at the time. A semiautomatic handgun was used in the shooting, and other guns were recovered in the home.
James Levels, 64, was killed and Lisa Prater, who is in her 40s, was wounded in a shooting in Warren, Ohio, late Monday. Police believe the shooting was a home invasion and have not identified a motive or suspects.
—WKBN
Desmond Holiday, 20, was killed when someone opened fire on his car in the Kingsway East neighborhood of St. Louis, Mo., Monday night. Others in the vehicle said someone pulled up alongside them, but no suspect information was released.
A 20-year-old man is fighting for his life after being shot six times in a home in the Feltonville neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pa., Tuesday afternoon. No arrests have been made and police did not release a motive.
A 25-year-old man was found shot to death in the middle of a street in Oceanside, Calif., Tuesday Tuesday night. Police said the neighborhood is a known gang area.
Eddie Johnson, 25, was found shot to death in the front yard of a home in Pueblo, Colo., early Tuesday. Police received a tip that led them to a house, where they arrested Taria Wilhite-Moore. No word on a motive.
—KRDO
Ronald Casillas, 24, was killed and an 18-year-old man was wounded in a shooting at a park on the west side of San Antonio, Tex., Tuesday afternoon. The two men had driven to the park to meet with three other men, and an argument escalated to gunfire. The suspects fled and are being sought.
—mySA
Christopher Turley, 23, was shot and killed in the parking lot of an apartment complex in Murfreesboro, Tenn., early Tuesday. An unidentified person was hospitalized with minor injuries. Anthony P. Smith, 22, was arrested. No motive was given.
Rodney Mullins, 43, was shot multiple times and killed at an apartment building in Bypro, Ky., Tuesday afternoon. Tyler Shehan, 23, was charged with murder. No word on a motive.
—WYMT
A 50-year-old man was critically wounded when someone wrestled a gun away from a man trying to rob a Chinese restaurant in the Kensington area of Philadelphia, Pa., early Tuesday. A female accomplice came running inside and tried to fight the victim’s friends before fleeing. Authorities are searching for the couple.
A 63-year-old man was shot through both ankles in the Beltzhoover neighborhood of Pittsburgh, Pa., late Tuesday.
Clinton Stonewall Jackson, Sr., 79, was shot and killed while driving in Newport News, Va., Tuesday evening. Investigators believe the shooter was riding in the vehicle with the victim. He fled after the car after it struck the corner of a parked vehicle and came to rest at a chain link fence.
—WAVY
One person was shot and wounded during a dispute with two men outside a home in Chapin, N.C., Tuesday afternoon. The suspects have been identified and are being sought.
Romuald Dwight Lawrence, 21, who was shot and wounded at a Shell gas station in Greensboro, N.C., early Sunday, died Tuesday afternoon. No arrests have been made.
A woman was shot and critically injured in Arlington, Wash., Tuesday afternoon. The circumstances of the shooting are not immediately known.
A man participating in an N.R.A. program at the Steel City Gun Club in Bethlehem, Pa., was wounded when he accidentally shot himself in the leg Tuesday afternoon. Several police officers and security agencies were taking part in the program.
Mitchell G. Large, 40, was shot and killed while breaking into someone’s home in Winter Haven, Fla., Monday morning. Luis A. Peña, 54, first fired a warning shot to deter the burglar, but fired again when Large charged at him. No arrests were made.
A man was shot in the stomach behind a Clarion Hotel in New Kensington, Pa., early Tuesday. Police have not determined a motive or named a suspect.
One person was shot and wounded on the near north Side of Peoria, Ill., Tuesday night. Several people are being questioned.
Antwan Anderson, 26, who was suspected in the disappearance of a woman and her son, fatally shot himself during a confrontation with police in Dayton, Ohio, Monday evening. Police had been searching for Anderson to question him about the whereabouts of Nichelle McKnight and her 4-year-old son, who have been missing since March 26.
Thomas Olson, 51, who was shot by his girlfriend’s ex-husband in Franklin County, Pa., Sunday morning, died Monday morning. Olson was visiting his girlfriend at her home when Roy Adams, 57, fought with the victim. Adam then shot and killed himself.
A 27-year-old man accidentally shot himself in the leg in Lincoln, Neb., Tuesday morning. Police believe the victim was sitting in a car with a friend when the gun he was holding discharged. It is the second accidental shooting in Lincoln in a week.
Three men were shot in Gary, Ind., over the weekend. On Saturday, Mondre Williams, 36, was shot while standing outside an apartment building. Bryan Robinson, 31, saw a car burning outside his home early Sunday, and when he stepped outside someone opened fire. On Sunday evening, Terrance Starks, 19, was visiting friends at a basement apartment when one of the men fired a handgun. Police believe the shooting was accidental.
A man was shot and killed near Joe’s Liquor & Food in Antioch, Calif., Tuesday afternoon. The circumstances of the shooting are not known.
A man in his 30s is in critical condition after being shot in a home invasion on the south side of Tucson, Ariz., early Tuesday. Witnesses said two men entered the home through a back window and a fight broke out between them and one of the occupants. The two men fled the scene.
A man was shot twice and critically wounded at a home in Phoenix, Ariz., early Tuesday. Police say there was a group of four or five people inside the home when someone shot the man. Witnesses at the home are not cooperating. The motive is not known.
—KSAZ
A 24-year-old appliance delivery man was shot and wounded in Akron, Ohio, Tuesday afternoon. Someone opened fire on a couple moving into a home, and one of the bullets traveled through the front door and a wall before striking the victim in the leg. Investigators are working to determine what prompted the shooting.
According to the Gun Violence Archive, 4,556 people have been injured by gun violence in America and 2,782 have been killed since Jan. 1, 2014.

article_title: The Gun Report: February 28, 2014
normalized_article_title: the gun report: february 28, 2014
text_content:
• With a bill allowing students and staff to carry guns on Idaho’s college campuses making its way through the state legislature, Greg Hampikian, a professor of biology and criminal justice at Boise State University, asks today in a Times Op-Ed, “When may I shoot a student?” The column, styled as a letter to the state legislature, continued, “Now that we’ll all be packing heat, I would like legal instruction in the rules of classroom engagement. … If I am working out a long equation on the board and several students try to correct me using their laser sights, am I allowed to fire a warning shot?”
At a public hearing on the bill, Boise’s police chief, who expressed grave concerns over the legislation, was not allowed to testify—but an N.R.A. spokesperson was allowed to speak for 40 minutes. More than 200 people protested against the bill on the Capitol steps yesterday.
• The N.R.A. sent a letter to Senate leaders urging them to reject Dr. Vivek Murthy, the president’s nominee for Surgeon General, over his belief that gun violence presents a major public health threat. The N.R.A. specifically criticized Murthy’s stance that doctors should ask patients about gun ownership and discuss gun safety procedures, his belief that more federal funding should be allocated for gun violence research, and his support for universal background checks and an assault weapons ban.
“Dr. Murthy’s record of political activism in support of radical gun control measures raises significant concerns about his ability to objectively examine issues pertinent to America’s 100 million firearm owners and the likelihood that he would use the office of the Surgeon General to further his preexisting campaign against gun ownership,” the letter read. Most major doctors’ groups treat gun violence as a public health concern.
• A Texas police sergeant who shot and killed his wife and then himself had appeared in a YouTube video five days earlier in which he reviewed a Mossberg 500 shotgun—that he said he purchased for his wife’s protection. Vanessa Pitofsky, 42, had told friends she was getting off Facebook because her husband, 47-year-old Nick Pitofsky, was very jealous. An avid gun and tactical gear enthusiast, Pitofsky had reviewed various weapons on Scout Tactical’s YouTube channel. “Nick was well respected by his peers and will be deeply missed by the city and department as a whole,” a statement from the Crandall police department read.
Here is today’s report.
—Jennifer Mascia
A 5-year-old boy was critically wounded in a possible drive-by shooting in Opelousas, La., Thursday afternoon. A 16-year-old boy was arrested.
—KLFY
A man and his 15-year-old son suffered gunshot wounds when they fended off a group of men who invaded their home in Salida, Calif., Wednesday night. A group of four or five men held the man, his wife and children at gunpoint while demanding cash and jewelry. The victims fought the men while the rest of the family escaped to a neighbor’s home. The suspects fled.
A 17-year-old boy was fatally shot on a sidewalk in Southeast Washington, D.C., Thursday afternoon. It is the ninth such fatal daylight attack so far this year.
A 17-year-old boy was shot and wounded in the Gresham neighborhood of Chicago early Thursday. In a separate shooting, a 23-year-old man was critically wounded while sitting in a car in the Grand Crossing neighborhood. No suspects are in custody in either shooting. A 24-year-old man was critically injured in a shooting in the West Garfield Park neighborhood Thursday afternoon. In yet another shooting, Eric Woods, 25, was fatally shot in the Lawndale neighborhood Thursday afternoon.
A 17-year-old boy was critically wounded and a 28-year-old was shot in the leg in eastern New Orleans, La., Thursday evening. Police have no suspects or a motive.
—WVUE
A teenage girl was shot on the near southeast side of Indianapolis, Ind., early Thursday. Police set up a checkpoint to capture the suspect but he escaped.
Michaela Lynne Jordan, 30, was shot to death at a home in Estherville, Ohio, Wednesday night. Scott Anthony Sudbeck, 35, has been charged with first-degree murder. Police aren’t saying how the two knew one another.
Richard Anthony Washington, 52, was shot to death following an argument with his son in Dundalk, Md., Thursday afternoon. Richard J. Washington, 18, is said to have shot his father several times with a large-caliber gun. He was taken into custody.
Lems Legrand, 20, was shot in an alley near his father’s store in the Oxford Circle neighborhood of Philadelphia, Pa., Wednesday night. The victim, who is now paralyzed, was working at the store when someone kicked in a rear door and shot him in the back. Police do not have suspects or a motive, but they are reviewing surveillance footage. The victim’s mother lost a son to gunfire during a dispute over a woman two years ago.
A 24-year-old man was shot five times and killed in the Germantown neighborhood of Philadelphia Thursday evening. Witnesses saw two men running from the scene into a nearby park. A short time earlier, an 18-year-old man was shot twice in the thigh in the West Oak Lane neighborhood.
Ricardo Meadows was shot 14 times in the Over-the-Rhine neighborhood of Cincinnati, Ohio, late Wednesday. Antonio Wethington was charged with aggravated assault. Police say Meadows and Wethington know each other but a motive has not yet been established.
—WCPO
Devion Russell-Reed, 21, was shot in the face and killed in an alley in north St. Louis, Mo., Thursday afternoon. No word on a motive or suspects.
Two women were wounded when someone fired into an apartment during a prayer service in Marion, Ohio, Thursday afternoon. Police said 59-year-old Terry Thacker accidentally discharged his shotgun into the floor. He was charged with negligent assault.
A woman was critically wounded when her son’s gun accidentally went off in Dayton, Nev., Thursday afternoon. The young man was showing his new gun to his father, and it discharged when he pulled it out of the holster, striking his mother in the leg. No one was taken into custody.
Timothy Davis, 18, was shot and wounded at a home in St. Joseph County, Ind., Thursday night. Police arrested 18-year-old Trey Lottie.
A man in his 30s was gravely wounded in a domestic shooting in the Park Hill neighborhood of Louisville, Ky., late Wednesday. No one has been charged. Neighbors said gun violence in the area is common. “People have to get together and start loving one another, and stop hating one another,” one resident said.
—WLKY
A 20-year-old man was shot in the leg during a marijuana sale in the Spring Valley area of San Diego, Calif., Thursday evening. During the transaction, the buyer took out a .45 caliber handgun and pointed it at the seller’s face. Deputies are looking for a 22-year-old suspect.
Samuel Kellam, 32, drove himself to the hospital after he was shot and wounded in Wilmington, N.C., Thursday afternoon. Witnesses told police that two cars were involved in the shooting. Police are soliciting tips.
A man was shot and critically wounded in a home in Kansas City, Mo., Thursday afternoon. Witnesses saw a suspect in a black coat fleeing the scene.
A 58-year-old man was found shot in the chest and wounded in a roadway in Fayetteville, N.C., Thursday evening. Officers have a person of interest in custody and a handgun was recovered at the scene.
A 41-year-old man was shot and killed in the East Ward of Newark, N.J., late Wednesday. No arrests have yet been made.
A man was shot multiple times and seriously wounded outside a home in York, Pa., Thursday night. The victim was able to speak to police at the scene, but they aren’t sure if the shooting was a random act.
Derrick Simmons, 43, was found shot and killed on a street corner in east Oakland, Calif., Wednesday evening. No arrests have been made.
A woman in her 30s was shot to death at an apartment complex in Albany, Ga., Thursday afternoon. Police are investigating.
A man was found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound at an apartment building in Normal, Ill., Thursday afternoon. Police had received a call shortly before the shooting about a man with a handgun making suicidal comments. Police made phone contact with the man, but he hung up.
A man was killed by a self-inflicted gunshot wound at a liquor store in Hamilton, N.Y., Wednesday morning. Tax officials had entered Cook’s Liquor Store with a police officer in order to seize it for nonpayment of back taxes when a gunshot rang out.
—WKTV
Chavez Lamar Spearman, 21, was found dead with a gunshot wound to the face in Sanford, N.C., Wednesday evening. The gun was recovered inside the vehicle.
Deandre Williams, 22, and Reshard Russ, 20, were wounded in a shooting at Barnes Park in Tampa, Fla., Thursday afternoon. Police said the victims were playing cards with friends when someone pulled up in a vehicle and confronted them. A nearby surveillance camera captured pictures of the suspect’s vehicle as it fled.
A police officer suffered shrapnel injuries to his leg when two suspected car thieves opened fire during a pursuit in Albuquerque, N.M., early Thursday. Justin Montgomery has been on the force since 2006. Antonio Delgadillo-Loera, 19, and Maria Guadalupe-Cruz, 18, were arrested.
Jeffrey S. Earhart, 38, was found shot to death at the at the F.R. Drake Company in Waynesboro, Va., Thursday morning, and a co-worker has been arrested. Boyd W. Wiseman, 54, reportedly shot the victim in a common area shared by workers. Police said there were no known problems between the men outside the workplace.
One man was killed and another man is in critical condition after a gang-related gun battle in southwest Fresno, Calif., Thursday afternoon. Police said the victims had been followed to the scene by several people in another vehicle. Officers are looking for suspects.
A man was shot in the head and wounded during a fight in Jackson, Miss., Thursday afternoon. A security guard said four cars pulled up and two of them began fighting. Police arrested Mario Luckett and charged him with aggravated assault.
—WAPT
A man was shot and wounded near downtown High Point, N.C., Thursday evening. The victim attempted to drive himself to the hospital but stopped the car and laid on the ground. A suspect has not been named.
—WGHP
According to the Gun Violence Archive, 2,726 people have been injured by gun violence in America and 1,646 have been killed since Jan. 1, 2014.

article_title: What We're Reading
normalized_article_title: what we're reading
text_content:
Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.
New York Review of Books
War Without Warriors
President Obama’s use of drones is a very divisive topic — issues of legality, overuse and national security are all raised. But often, a lot of nuance is lost in the debate over drones, and this piece does a good job of looking at the issue in a measured way. It is a complex topic, and much thought is required. This piece is a good place to start. — Prashant Rao
Humans of New York
Opting to Serve
Elliot Ackerman, who first caught my attention with a short essay that wove together his love of skateboarding and his experience of war, was featured this month in a series called “Invisible Wounds,” a collection of stories from veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan. His reflections, as captured in these tweets by Humans of New York’s Brandon Stanton, convey an important message about war and military service — and about the role that privilege can play on the battlefield. — Stephen Hiltner
The Ringer
Liberate the Platform
The recent boom in podcasting has encouraged young, brown women to take up some bandwidth in a traditionally, male-dominated medium, and on their own terms. — Jenna Wortham
The Stranger
In Plain Sight
Doctored drinks, date rape and compromised ability to consent are things many of us tend to associate with college parties. But this terrific story dives into another reality — that it could happen in a public place, in this case, a crowded bar full of people in one of Seattle’s coolest neighborhoods. And it raises a powerful question: What level of security, or even surveillance, should exist in places where people go to let loose? — Kirk Johnson
The Economist
¿Qué Hora Es?
Spain is known for its leisurely (and late) hours. But since World War II, it has been in the wrong time zone, and Spaniards have actually been losing sleep over it. This short piece explains how Spain ended up in such a predicament, and why momentum is building to change the clocks and put the country back in sync with the sun. — Gina Lamb

article_title: What We're Reading
normalized_article_title: what we're reading
text_content:
Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.
The Public Eye
Roots
We tend to think of mass surveillance as a relatively new phenomenon, but a new book, “Dark Matters: On the Surveillance of Blackness,” argues that the history of tracking individuals in the United States began with slavery. This Q. and A. with the author, Simone Browne, an expert on the African diaspora, is endlessly fascinating and eye-opening. — Jenna Wortham
Vice
Close at Hand
In this video, Edward Snowden takes Vice’s co-founder, Shane Smith, through mobile phone mechanics and shows how the device is not only a tracking beacon, but also easily hacked for data theft and/or real-time monitoring. Certainly something to be aware of as we increasingly rely on our smartphones, and also when we head to the polls in November. — Mark Borden
Aeon
The Early Geeks
Artificial intelligence, eternal life, technologies to control nature — whatever tech has in mind, the ancient Greeks got there first. A look at their myths offers some excellent cautionary lessons. — Quentin Hardy
The New York Review of Books
The Other Knopf
Loved this piece by Francine Prose on a new book about yet another important woman you’ve barely heard of. Blanche Knopf, wife of Alfred, “profoundly and permanently influenced the American public’s ideas about, and taste in, literature.” She helped nurture and publish everyone from Langston Hughes and Nella Larsen to Willa Cather, Muriel Spark, Elizabeth Bowen and Raymond Chandler, and introduced American readers to Thomas Mann, Sigmund Freud, Albert Camus, Simone de Beauvoir and others, without getting much, if any, credit. — Julie Bloom
Slate
The Borrowers
The commencement season has ended on U.S. campuses, but the black market for dissertations never appears to end in Russia. A group called Dissernet, which utilizes text-combing software, has been exposing extensive plagiarism among politicians and academics. So far, they’ve found major copying in the dissertations of more than 1,000 high-achieving Russians. Students in Russia, and elsewhere, may want to think twice before hitting “paste.” — Adeel Hassan
McSweeney’s
Final Hopes and Dreams
For all those students relieved to have completed their classes, there’s the flip side: the teachers and professors who now must hunker down to grade those final papers. As an adjunct university professor, I can relate. Here’s an amusing piece from one professor about all the things that she’d rather be doing. Base jumping off a parking garage, anyone? — Lynda Richardson

article_title: The Gun Report: March 26, 2014
normalized_article_title: the gun report: march 26, 2014
text_content:
More women are carrying concealed weapons than ever before. A quarter of the one million permits issued in Florida are held by women, many of whom are flooding concealed permit classes.
“It is over 50 percent (women) now taking our class, where it was maybe 10 percent a few years back,” Z Farhat, an employee at Green Acres Sporting Goods in Jacksonville, told First Coast News. Women cite personal safety as their chief reason for carrying. “All you have to do is sit down and watch the news and there’s a shooting almost every night or more,” said a businesswoman who did not want to be identified.
In Missouri, women who had never touched a handgun are signing up for firearms training in droves. “If something happens, I want to know what to do,” Anita Haley told KFVS during a target-training class in Scott County. “You could save your own life or someone else’s.” Delisa Sitze, a music teacher who was also taking the class, said it’s about “empowerment,” then hit her target 40 out of 40 times.
And the gun industry is catering to this flourishing demographic. PinkHandguns.com supplies women with a fashionable self-defense option. Bling Bullets advertises “Defense with style!” and sells bullets adorned with gemstones and crystals. Smith & Wesson sponsors a website called NRAWomen.TV, which airs such shows as “Armed and Fabulous,” about women who “have dedicated their lives to protecting our Second Amendment rights,” and “Love at First Shot,” which features first-time shooters.
But Mary Anne Franks of the University of Miami’s law school warns that packing heat to prevent such crimes as rape at the hands of strangers may not help. “Of all the interpersonal threats women and girls are likely to face in their lifetimes, stranger rape is one of the rarest,” she writes on Huffington Post. “The vast majority of rape victims—more than two-thirds—are assaulted by someone they know.”
Like Christy Salters Martin, a professional boxer, whose abusive husband grabbed the gun she was trying to defend herself with and shot her. “Having a gun isn’t enough,” she said last fall.
Here is today’s report.
—Jennifer Mascia
David Utz, 43, was shot and killed by his wife, who didn’t realize the gun was loaded, in Hillsboro, Mo., Saturday evening. Authorities say Utz, his 29-year-old wife and friends were looking at guns in their home. Utz loaded a gun and set it down, and when his wife returned to the room, she picked it up and somehow fired a single shot into her husband’s chest. The prosecutor’s office will determine whether charges will be filed.
A man and woman are dead following a murder-suicide in northwest Kalispell, Mont., early Tuesday. Just after midnight, a man called police and said his father had just shot his mother and was going to commit suicide. By the time law officers arrived, the man was dead.
A woman was killed in a domestic shooting at a home in Mobile, Ala., Tuesday morning. A man is in custody. It’s unclear what led up to the shooting.
Angie Cantrell, 53, was shot in the shoulder by her boyfriend, 53-year-old Lloyd K. Kruckebery, who then committed suicide at an apartment in Whitestown, Ind., Monday night. Cantrell had tried to break up with Kruckebery earlier that evening.
Gene Kennedy, 79, was shot and killed by his daughter, 54-year-old Debra A. McCawley, who then killed herself at a home in Elmwood, Ill., Tuesday morning. No word on a motive.
A woman was shot and killed in a domestic incident in the Lauderhill area of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., Tuesday morning. Yohaniz Ceballos Palomino, 26, as charged with second-degree murder. Neighbors said the young couple lived in the apartment and often argued. They had at least three kids, including an infant. Someone in a nearby apartment said the suspect had previously threatened to kill the victim.
Seibert H. Prescott, 63, and Roger O. Bennett, 30, were shot and killed during an argument among a group of five men in Fort Lauderdale Tuesday afternoon. The victims were arguing with three men, and when they attempted to flee, one of the men opened fire. The gunman’s identity is unknown.
Six people were injured in a shooting outside an apartment in Stockton, Calif., Monday night. Witnesses said they saw a vehicle pull into an empty lot next to the complex and an unknown number of people got out of the vehicle and opened fire. Police do not have any suspect information.
—KCRA
A 15-year-old boy was injured in a shooting on the south side of Syracuse, N.Y., Tuesday night. Police said the victim was standing with two friends in front of a barber shop when they were approached by four men, one of whom opened fire. The suspects were last spotted fleeing the scene in a car.
Two men were shot and killed while breaking into a home in Detroit, Mich., Tuesday morning. The homeowner, 51, is cooperating with police. His home had been broken into last week. This is the ninth time this year that a homeowner has shot and killed an intruder in Detroit.
A 27-year-old woman was shot in the thigh during a home invasion robbery on the west side of Erie, Pa., early Tuesday. Three men wearing masks reportedly kicked in the front door and pushed the five people into a bedroom, threatening to beat up the occupants unless they gave them everything they had. The thieves managed to steal an iPhone before fleeing. The victims said they could not identify the suspects.
Two women were critically injured and a man was wounded in a shooting in south Baltimore, Md., Tuesday night. No suspect or motive was identified by police.
Dresan Armstrong, 18, was killed and a 17-year-old boy was injured in a shooting in east Columbus, Ohio, Tuesday night. Detectives say the motive is unknown.
A man was found shot to death in a pickup truck in the Arlington area of Jacksonville, Fla., Tuesday evening. The shooter, who lives on the street where the body was found, remained at the scene and police took him into custody. The motive is unknown. In a separate shooting, a man in his late 40s or early 50s was shot during an argument in northwest Jacksonville.
Lavonte Ingram, 20, was shot to death in front of several witnesses in a parking lot in Cocoa, Fla., early Tuesday. A man reportedly approached the victim and opened fire with a handgun. He fled on foot.
—WESH
A 50-year-old woman was found shot to death in a south Philadelphia, Pa., home Tuesday afternoon. She was found in the bedroom of a home, along with a gun and four shell casings. No word on a suspect.
Roger Tucker was shot in the stomach during a heated argument outside a motel in Hialeah, Fla., Tuesday morning. Police said the victim, who is transient, knew the suspect, Philip De Falco, for years. After the shooting, De Falco called police and surrendered his gun. He later claimed to have opened fire in self-defense, but surveillance video from the motel tells a different story.
A man was shot in the arm with an assault rifle after two groups of people exchanged words at a bar in San Antonio, Tex., early Tuesday. Police are searching for the suspect.
—KSAT
A man in his 20s ran into a Jack in the Box restaurant with a gunshot wound to the leg in Las Vegas, Nev., Tuesday night. Police said the victim was shot in the parking lot and the incident may be gang-related. Three men were spotted fleeing the scene.
—KVVU
An 18-year-old man was shot and seriously wounded at Mirasol Park in Tucson, Ariz., Tuesday night. Police are investigating.
A 21-year-old man was fatally shot at an apartment complex near Stone Mountain, Ga., early Tuesday. Investigators have not revealed a motive.
A man was shot at a convenience store in Fairfield, Ala., Tuesday evening. An off-duty officer took two suspects into custody, but the suspect believed to be the shooter was able to flee the scene.
Felix Avelar, a convenience store clerk, is in critical condition after he was shot during a robbery at the store in Long Beach, Calif., Monday night. “He held my hand tight,” the victim’s son, Sergio Avelar, said. “I told him we would get through this.” The shooter or shooters remain at large.
—KTLA
Ahmed Shahit, 55, a store clerk, was shot and killed during a robbery at a gas station in Henderson, N.C., late Monday. Police said two men entered the Best Bet Food Mart and demanded money. Friends said Shahit was from Yemen, where his wife and children live. “It’s bad when you’ve got to kill a person to obtain the money he’s worked for,” a customer said.
—WRAL
David Welch, 33, and Shaquana Kinds, 23, were shot during a firefight in the parking lot of a gas station on the east side of Cleveland, Ohio, early Tuesday. Welch gave disparate accounts of the shooting and eventually stopped cooperating with investigators. Kinds told police that several men began shooting at each other.
Charles Murphree shot and killed himself near mile marker 154 on Interstate 24 in Marion County, Tenn., Tuesday afternoon. Officers spotted the victim’s van in the parking lot of Western Sizzlin’ restaurant. He fled the scene, pulled over and killed himself.
A 40-year-old man being investigated for crimes related to child pornography was found dead of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head inside his submerged car in Lake Jacomo in Blue Springs, Mo., Tuesday. A witness called police after seeing a car speed into the water. The sheriff’s office says the investigation has now been closed.
A 19-year-old man is in critical condition after being shot in downtown New Orleans, La., Tuesday afternoon. After gunfire broke out on the main thoroughfare, passersby stopped to watch the investigation and snap photos. Police arrested two brothers shortly after the shooting.
Richard St. Lawrence, 61, was shot to death during an argument with a woman in his southeast Houston, Tex., home Tuesday morning. The woman was taken into custody.
Wayne Patrick Cooper, 36, a known gang member, was shot to death in an S.U.V. parked outside an apartment complex in Downey, Calif., early Tuesday. Police believe the shooting was gang-related. Two suspects have been booked for murder.
Two people were shot and killed in Newnan, Ga., Tuesday night. Investigators found a man lying dead in the street. Police said they are interviewing witnesses but have not released a motive.
An 18-year-old man marijuana dealer was shot in the leg in a park in far east Wichita, Kan., Monday afternoon. Police said two teens were at the park to sell pot when the suspect approached their car and tapped on the window with a gun. The boys tried to drive away when the suspect reportedly opened fire. Police are searching for the suspect.
—KAKE
A 23-year-old man was struck in the neck in a drug-related shooting in Holyoke, Mass., Tuesday afternoon. Two men were taken into custody.
A 38-year-old man was shot and seriously wounded in his home in the Koreatown neighborhood of Chicago Monday night. After a threatening phone call, a bullet came through the window and hit the victim in the groin. Multiple people are being questioned.
According to the Gun Violence Archive, 3,908 people have been injured by gun violence in America and 2,396 have been killed since Jan. 1, 2014.

article_title: The Gun Report: December 10, 2013
normalized_article_title: the gun report: december 10, 2013
text_content:
Friday marked the 20th anniversary of a gun massacre on the Long Island Rail Road in New York that claimed six lives and left 19 wounded. On Dec. 7, 1993—six years before Columbine—Colin Ferguson, a 35-year-old Jamaican immigrant, boarded a commuter train during the evening rush hour armed with a nine-millimeter semiautomatic Ruger pistol and a small duffel bag jammed with ammunition. He opened fire as the train approached the Merillon Avenue Station.
While reloading his third magazine, passengers Michael O’Connor, Kevin Blum and Mark McEntee tackled Ferguson and pinned him down. Before police arrived, Ferguson said, “O, God, what did I do? What did I do? I deserve whatever I get.”
Detectives said it appeared Ferguson had been planning the shooting for more than a week. Chief Joseph Flynn of the Long Island Rail Road police said, “This was the work of a deranged, maniacal person who for a variety of reasons decided to explode.” Ferguson had reportedly become obsessed with racial issues in America, speaking in the third person about “some apocryphal-type doom scenario” that included black people rising up and striking down “their pompous rulers and oppressors.” Ferguson would later fire his attorneys and represent himself at trial. He was found guilty and sentenced to 315 years and eight months; his earliest possible parole date is August 6, 2309.
In the wake of the shooting, President Clinton instructed Attorney General Janet Reno to review a proposal by incoming New York City mayor Rudy Giuliani that would set up a national uniform licensing system for gun buyers. It was to include background checks, tests and required renewals every two years. Needless to say, that didn’t happen.
Dennis McCarthy, a 52-year-old office manager at Prudential Securities, was killed, and his son, Kevin, was severely injured. Three years later, McCarthy’s widow, Carolyn, was elected to the House of Representatives. She campaigned on one issue: gun control.
Here is today’s report.
—Jennifer Mascia
Aubrey Peters, 16, who was hailed as a hero for helping save two young girls who fell through the ice at a reservoir in 2010, was killed when a man shot her with a handgun he thought was empty in Noblesville, Ind., late Sunday. Jacob Travis McDaniel, 20, was showing Peters and two other men a shotgun and a handgun. He tried to get the victim to hold the gun, but she didn’t want to. He then ejected the magazine from the gun, pointed the weapon at her, took the safety off and pulled the trigger. He was charged with reckless homicide.
A man went on a random shooting spree through a neighborhood in Fresno, Calif., late Sunday, seriously injuring two people. Johnny Nunez-Lopez, 21, fired as many as 15 shots. A neighbor disarmed him and held him until deputies arrived.
Sinouane Nanthabouthdy, 37, and Inpanh Nathabouthdy, 58, were shot and killed in a home in Mt. Airy, Ga., Sunday afternoon. Police believe the shooting is domestic. Two children in the home at the time were not hurt.
A 28-year-old man was shot and killed during a robbery at the West Park RTA station in Cleveland, Ohio, Monday night. Police said three men attempted to rob the victim and his friend, and as the two attempted to flee, one of the alleged robbers fired one shot, hitting the victim in the chest. The suspects then robbed the victim and left the scene on foot. They are at large.
A 17-year-old boy was dropped off at a hospital following a drive-by shooting in Rockford, Ill., Monday night. Police said gunshots were fired from the passenger-side window of a red, four-door vehicle.
Shane Stein, 17, was shot in the arm during an attempted robbery outside at a beverage store in Warren, Ohio, Sunday night. The shooter fled. Police are reviewing video footage obtained from the store’s surveillance camera.
An 18-year-old woman was shot in the neck and wounded at an apartment complex in Maple Grove, Minn., Sunday night. A neighbor told police a domestic assault preceded the gunshot, but police suggested the shooting was accidental. A 22-year-old man was taken into custody for reckless discharge of a firearm.
A 43-year-old woman was shot and killed after an argument at an apartment in Killeen, Tex., early Monday. The suspect, a 41-year-old man, held a witness hostage before she escaped and called police. The suspect was arrested after a two-hour SWAT standoff.
A woman was killed by a self-inflicted gunshot to the head in a parked car in Johnson City, Tenn., Monday night. A witness arrived home at a nearby apartment complex and came upon the victim, who was threatening to kill herself.
Andrew West was killed, and Marcello Bryant and Terrell Evan were wounded, in a shooting at an automotive shop in New Bern, N.C., Monday morning. Police said the shooter and his victims knew each other. They are investigating whether self-defense was involved.
Two people were killed in a home in the Polish Village area of north Toledo, Ohio, late Monday. At least 10 shots were fired toward the house. Relatives shrieked and wailed in the aftermath of the violence. Police are searching for two suspects.
A 19-year-old man was hit by gunfire as he was walking in the Sunnydale neighborhood of San Francisco, Calif., Monday evening. No suspect information is available.
A 21-year-old man was killed and a 21-year-old man was wounded in a shooting in North Valley Stream, N.Y., Monday night. Joshua Geddes, 23, was arrested. A motive is not known.
April Infinger, 32, was shot and killed in a bar in Summerville, S.C., early Sunday. The victim was struck by a bullet as a large group of people fought outside. Shearon Lamar Bennett, 33, a felon with a lengthy rap sheet, was arrested.
A 30-year-old man was shot and wounded outside a home in Summerville, S.C., Sunday night. Witnesses said the victim was getting ready to leave when two vehicles drove by and four to five gunshots rang out. Emergency room staff said the victim told them several different stories about how the injury happened, and he was uncooperative with police.
Racieh Robinson, 28, was shot in the face and killed following an argument in Moultrie, Ga., Monday afternoon. Lenorris Jordan, 23, who police found hiding in a semi truck, is charged with murder.
William “Stan” Brewer, 37, was killed with a shotgun wielded by his wife in Brighton, Tenn., early Sunday. Angela Brewer originally told deputies she shot and killed her husband after she heard an intruder outside, but later admitted to pointing the gun at the victim’s head while he slept. The couple’s two children were home at the time. Police are baffled as to a motive. Brewer was charged with second-degree murder.
John Stiller, 69, was wounded in a shooting in Kelso, Wash., early Monday. The man’s roommate, 43-year-old Linda Cochran, called 911 and told police she was the shooter. She remained on the line and continued to shoot a rifle randomly until deputies arrived.
A 36-year-old man was shot in the foot and leg in New Orleans, La., late Sunday. Police said a white Chevy Impala drove past the victim while someone in the rear passenger seat opened fire. The shooting is under investigation.
A man was shot and wounded in a home in Gary, Ind., Sunday afternoon. The victim was fighting with his mother when the shooter intervened. He faces a charge of criminal recklessness.
A 28-year-old man was injured in a shooting in an alley in the University Village neighborhood of Chicago, Ill., early Monday. Police believe someone in a dark-colored van opened fire, striking the victim as he sat in a car. No suspects are in custody.
Two people were wounded in a shooting in Cocoa, Fla., Monday afternoon. Steven Jackson, 25, told police he didn’t know who shot him. A friend picked him up and drove him to a fire station. The second victim, 40, was shot in the hand and drove himself to the hospital. Investigators discovered that a fight preceded the shooting. No word on arrests.
Two people were critically wounded in a shooting in Petersburg, Va., Monday evening. A family member of one of the victims said there were multiple crime scenes. Police are developing suspect descriptions.
Samuel L. Smalls, 22, was shot and killed in Buffalo, N.Y., Sunday night. The victim was with two other men when a gunman approached and began firing. Anyone with information is urged to call police.
A man said he was abducted, robbed and shot after a trip to SugarHouse Casino in Philadelphia, Pa., early Monday. The victim said three men grabbed him, threw him into a van and took $3,800 before shooting him and throwing him on the street. No word on suspects.
A woman was shot in the Ashburton neighborhood of Baltimore, Md., Sunday morning. Dontay Jones, 29, was arrested on charges of attempted first-degree murder and domestic assault.
A 48-year-old man was shot and wounded when two men came into his Radford, Va., apartment and demanded money early Monday. Kevin Dale Scott Sheppard, 21, Clinton Wade Dillon, 25, and Tonio Donavalle Belcher-Wade, 19, were arrested.
A man was shot by one of his accomplices while robbing a woman’s home in Fond-du-Lac County, Wis., early Sunday. The wounded man was taken to a hospital with life-threatening injuries, and the other two suspects, 20 and 22, were arrested.
—WBAY
A man was found suffering from a gunshot wound in the parking lot of the Hills Homes Housing complex in Springfield, Mass., Monday night. Four suspects were taken into custody. No word on a motive.
—WGGB
A man was shot in the buttocks in a drive-by shooting in Jacksonville, Fla., Monday afternoon, blocks form where Johnathan Corey Youngblood, 30, was shot and killed the day before. Police did not say if the two shootings were linked or provide a description of the vehicle or the suspects.
Christopher Moeller, 24, was critically injured in a shooting in east Columbus, Ohio, Monday night. The victim was walking up the driveway to his home when a masked man asked him for his car keys and shot him four times with a handgun. No arrests have been made.
According to Slate’s gun-death tracker, an estimated 11,376 people have died as a result of gun violence in America since the Newtown massacre on December 14, 2012.

article_title: The Gun Report: November 20, 2013
normalized_article_title: the gun report: november 20, 2013
text_content:
Supporters of an initiative to prevent Washington state from adopting universal background checks for gun sales have collected 340,000 signatures, The Seattle Times reported yesterday. Initiative 591 would prevent the state from adopting background-check laws stricter than the national standard, which does not require checks for private gun sales.
Alan Gottlieb, founder of the Second Amendment Foundation, said nearly 900 volunteers have participated in the effort. “I’m not surprised at this kind of response,” he said. “Gun owners have been under attack for more than a year now.”
The proposal was crafted in response to Initiative 594, which seeks to require background checks for all sales. Supporters of that initiative submitted about 250,000 signatures last month. Both measures are aimed at the 2014 ballot.
On Sunday, a Seattle Times columnist wrote about Tina Podlodowski, a former Seattle City Council member and gun control advocate, who purchased a 9-mm Beretta for $300 on Armslist, no questions asked—and no background check. The sale was conducted in a Shoreline, Wash., parking lot.
“I could have been anybody and they could have been anybody,” she said. Here is today’s report.
—Jennifer Mascia
Virginia State Senator R. Creigh Deeds, 55, was stabbed repeatedly at his Bath County, Va., home during an altercation with his son, who then shot and killed himself Tuesday morning. The day before, state mental health officials unsuccessfully sought to find a bed in a hospital psychiatric ward for Gus Deeds, 24, who had known mental health problems. “In that particular rural area of the state, it is not unusual to have contacted anywhere from seven to 15 hospitals” looking for an available bed, said Mary Ann Bergeron, the executive director of the Virginia Association of Community Services Boards. No word on how Deeds got a gun.
A 7-year-old girl was shot in the elbow and seriously wounded at an apartment complex on the northwest side of Indianapolis, Ind., Tuesday evening. Detectives said the shooting was not random. No arrests have been made.
An 8-year-old boy and his father were shot and wounded in Irvington, N.J., Sunday afternoon. Lloyd Lemonious was shot in the leg and his son was shot in the cheek. Investigators do not believe the victims were the intended targets. Police released surveillance images of a man running from the scene who is wanted for questioning.
A 14-year old boy was accidentally shot in the arm with a hunting rifle while riding in a vehicle with his father in the mountains above York, Mont., Monday. Their truck bounced across a hole in the road and the rifle, a Remington M77 model 30-06 caliber, discharged. Had the shot entered the child’s arm an inch closer to his body, he would have lost the arm at the shoulder. No charges were filed.
A woman shot herself in the thigh while hunting in Mayville, Mich., Monday afternoon. Her injuries are life-threatening.
Traci Reedy, 48, was shot and killed at an Irving, Tex., hotel by a guest whose gun fired from another room early Tuesday. The victim was sitting on her bed at the Microtel Inn and Suites when a bullet came through the wall and struck her in the chest. Michael Shane Gray, 36, was arrested and charged with criminally negligent homicide. If convicted, he faces between 180 days to two years in jail.
—WFAA
Gloria E. Zuniga, 59, was killed when someone opened fire on her house in Milwaukee, Wis., Monday night. Police say the shooting is gang-related, and the victim was not the target. No arrests have been made.
A 30-year-old woman was killed in a drive-by shooting on a residential street in Mesa, Ariz., early Tuesday. The shooting was sparked by a dispute between two groups at a house party. Police have no suspects in custody.
A 28-year-old woman was shot and killed at an apartment in Traverse City, Mich., Tuesday night. The suspect, a 33-year-old man, sustained a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the hand. He was arrested.
Stephanie Barrios, 29, was shot and killed in her ex-boyfriend’s car, which was parked outside her home in Woodbridge, N.J., Monday night. The ex-boyfriend, 46-year-old Luis Rosado, then shot and killed himself.
A man in his 30s was shot several times and killed following an argument inside a Santa Ana, Calif., pool hall early Tuesday. Two people were arrested.
42-year-old Rupert E. Miley was shot in the back and killed while driving in Orem, Utah, early Tuesday. His vehicle then struck a light pole, plowed into some trees and destroyed a fire hydrant. A revolver was found at the scene. Two passengers in the car were arrested.
Brandon Torres, 21, who was shot in the Back of the Yards neighborhood of Chicago, Ill., early Sunday, died the next day. The victim was in the backseat of a vehicle when a gunman on the street opened fire. No one is in custody.
Porshia Brooks, 20, who was shot while sitting in her car in Norwood, Ohio, Saturday night, died Tuesday morning. Aron Martin, who was standing outside the car covered in blood, remains in critical condition. Anyone with information is asked to call police.
20-year-old Cody Jamal Harris was shot and killed at a park in Bakersfield, Calif., Monday night. A suspect is being sought.
A 26-year-old man was shot and wounded while driving on Interstate 70 in St. Louis, Mo., Tuesday afternoon. The victim was riding in a vehicle with three other adults and a baby when shots were fired at him from another car. Police said the incident was sparked by an argument that occurred before both cars got on the highway. The baby suffered abrasions.
17-year-old Javonte Townsend was shot in the leg in Lumberton, N.C., Monday night. No word on suspects.
A 17-year-old boy was shot in the arm while standing on the porch of a Des Moines, Iowa, home Monday night. Witnesses heard six gunshots. No arrests have been reported.
Nathaniel Cook, 18, was shot and wounded in north Omaha, Neb., Monday night. Police are investigating.
One person was shot and killed at a Rock Hill, S.C., apartment complex Tuesday evening. Witnesses told officers they saw three men running from the scene.
A man was shot and wounded outside his home in Slidell, La., Sunday afternoon. The victim said two men wearing masks approached him and demanded cash. When he said he didn’t have any money, one of the men shot him.
A man in his late teens or early 20s was shot in the head and wounded in Muskegon Heights, Mich., Tuesday night.
A 53-year-old man was shot three times after answering a knock on the door to his apartment on the east side of Evansville, Ind., Tuesday evening. Robert Hill told police he opened the door and fought with two men, one of whom opened fire. A manhunt is underway. Hill was the victim of a shooting in the same neighborhood earlier this year.
A woman was grazed by a bullet north of Robles Park in Tampa, Fla., Tuesday evening. Police are searching for a male suspect.
A woman was shot in the hand when a man tried to rob her outside her home in Greenville County, S.C., Tuesday evening. The robber fled empty-handed. Residents in the neighborhood said they are fed up with the violence and are ready to move.
According to Slate’s gun-death tracker, an estimated 10,706 people have died as a result of gun violence in America since the Newtown massacre on December 14, 2012.

article_title: Chinese Ex-General Warns U.S. Over Magazine Article
normalized_article_title: chinese ex-general warns u.s. over magazine article
text_content:
“A reminder to the Americans puffed up with pride and arrogance, making threatening gestures: Do not be ultimately defeated by our lethal trump weapon in your absent-mindedness.”
So went the stern warning issued last Friday by retired Lt. Gen. Wang Hongguang in the populist Chinese newspaper Global Times.
But General Wang’s ire was not aimed at the Pentagon’s annual report on the Chinese military, published last week, but rather an earlier article in the American magazine The National Interest, titled “Five American Weapons of War China Should Fear.”
In it, the author, Kyle Mizokami, while assuring readers that the chances of war between China and the United States are remote, listed the weapons “China likely fears most,” including American aircraft carriers, the fifth-generation F-22 Raptor jet and the Virginia-class submarine. The article was published in mid-May but has only recently been circulating in Chinese translation.
It apparently hit a sore spot with General Wang, who retired in 2012 after serving as deputy commander of the Nanjing Military Region. He said the article was “full of flaws” and deserved a rebuttal. He did not mention an earlier article by Mr. Mizokami, which listed the “Five Chinese Weapons of War America Should Fear.”
General Wang argued against the usefulness of a list of individual weapons, saying that battles are fought more broadly between the forces of both sides and that the author’s approach shows him to be “extremely unprofessional.”
General Wang also boasted of China’s ability to defend itself against United States aircraft carriers, which The National Interest article said “represent a threat not only to Chinese naval and air forces away from China, but could strike China itself.” The article argued that the United States carriers “represent a showcase of technologies that China hasn’t mastered.”
While acknowledging that American technology is “truly much more advanced” than China’s, General Wang said that China’s missile arsenal could counter American carriers. China’s sole aircraft carrier, the Liaoning, is a refitted Soviet-era ship purchased from Ukraine and was the object of much national pride in China when it was relaunched in 2012.
The general also took umbrage at the article’s unfavorable comparison of Chinese with American jets and aircraft defense systems. Mr. Mizokami argued, for example, that the American F-22 jets’ ability to evade radar meant it “can likely penetrate Chinese air defenses.”
Without revealing exactly what systems he had in mind — “for secrecy reasons” — General Wang said that China had “many types” of aircraft detection systems.
“May I suggest to Americans, when using stealth aircraft it’s best to keep away from the Chinese mainland. Remember! Remember!” he warned.
China has long resented American air and ship surveillance in its Exclusive Economic Zone. In 2001, a collision between a U.S. Navy EP-3 reconnaissance plane and a Chinese fighter jet off the coast of Hainan Province led to a diplomatic crisis. After the encounter, in which the Chinese pilot was killed, China detained the 24 American crew members for more than a week.
General Wang’s resentment of United States criticism of the People’s Liberation Army’s capabilities had apparently been building for some time. He wrote, “In recent years, there are always some Americans jumping out with wildly arrogant remarks, belittling China’s combat ability including weapons and equipment level.”
He wrote that China’s military equipment was undergoing rapid development that would make people look at it in “a new light.”
He also posited fundamental differences in the national character of China versus the United States. Although he insisted such attributes were “just a characteristic” and neither good nor bad, he described the American national character as “outgoing, arrogant and flamboyant.” The Chinese character, he said, was “introverted, modest, tolerant and not flamboyant in action.”
It is unclear to what extent General Wang’s comments represent the views of Chinese military and civilian policy makers. However, it seems clear that his retirement has given him a public voice that serving officers do not enjoy.
“In the past, although I wanted to refute some wildly arrogant views I saw from Americans who did not know their own limitations, because of the constraints of secrecy, I could only suppress the truth in my heart,” he wrote.
This is also not the first time that General Wang has spoken out about strategic issues and international affairs. He has been one of the rare Chinese military officers to have publicly criticized North Korea. In March, he said that North Korea’s launch of a short-range rocket that crossed the trajectory of a Chinese civilian airliner was “a rather unfriendly attitude” and “highly risky.”

article_title: The Gun Report: February 26, 2014
normalized_article_title: the gun report: february 26, 2014
text_content:
We have written before about gun sales transpiring on Instagram and Reddit, mostly without background checks. Now we can add Facebook, where photos of breastfeeding mothers are censored, but gun sales continue unabated.
Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America recently created a spot styled after Facebook’s recent 10th anniversary “ A Look Back” videos—compiling the highlights of each user’s activity since they joined the social network—which features gun adverts posted on users’ profiles and gun sales groups where users congregate and peddle their wares.
“Anyone can buy and sell guns without criminal background checks,” the video warns. The organization is spearheading an effort to get gun sales banned from Facebook and Instagram, and a press rep at Mayors Against Illegal Guns told us that, so far, Facebook has been receptive to a discussion on how to fix the policy. Craigslist, eBay and Google have banned the buying, selling or trading of firearms on their sites without background checks.
Last October, a 15-year-old boy brought a 9mm handgun to a Kentucky high school that he had purchased from a convicted felon on Facebook. The man, who lived in Ashland, Ohio, arranged the sale through the Portsmouth Pickers Facebook group. On Feb. 19, police caught 21-year-old William Kurtz, a convicted felon from Storm Lake, Iowa, attempting to acquire weapons via Facebook. In a transaction with an undercover officer, Kurtz allegedly exchanged an AR-15 assault rifle for a .45 caliber semi-automatic handgun.
Here is today’s report.
—Jennifer Mascia
Four people were killed and another was critically wounded in a domestic shooting at a home in Glade Spring, Va., early Tuesday. Armed with two guns, Kevin Dale Palmer, 44, broke into his in-laws’ house where his wife and son were staying and an argument erupted. Palmer killed his mother-in-law, Nancy Griffin, 74; his wife, Kristen, 46; and her son, Griffin, 17. Palmer also wounded his father-in-law, Terry Griffin, 75, before killing himself. A protective order had previously been issued against Palmer.
Three girls, ages 10, 15 and 18, were wounded when a vehicle pulled up and someone inside opened fire in the Liberty City neighborhood of Miami, Fla., Tuesday afternoon. Jacqueline Powell, 18, was grazed in the cheek, neck, armpit and stomach, and 10-year-old Deshareah Wright was shot in the arm. Police are searching for suspects.
A man and two women were found shot to death at a home in Rochester, N.Y., Monday morning. Jermeliah and Jacquelyn Simmons, who were cousins, were found by their stepfather. The family of the third victim, Michael Nelson, said his father had been a murder victim 18 years ago. The mothers of the two cousins are being protected in a secret location as police investigate.
—WHEC
Cartrial Robertson, 13, was shot and killed while he and a friend played with a gun at a home in Memphis, Tenn., Tuesday morning. Darrin Wilson, 15, was charged with reckless homicide. A man who lives at the home said he and his girlfriend were at work and her teenage boys were home alone.
—WREG
A 24-year-old man and a 29-year-old woman were found shot to death following a police chase in Alexandria, Minn., Monday night. The victims, who were from North Dakota, were sitting in a car in a driveway when they were approached by an officer. They shot him in the chest—the bullet was stopped by his bulletproof vest—and fled. Their bodies were located in the woods after their car got stuck in snow.
Cheryl Gilberg, 43, was shot in the head and killed in her home in Mazomanie, Wis., Sunday night. The victim had notified law enforcement earlier this month that she was a victim of domestic abuse. No suspects have been identified and detectives said they were following several strong leads.
Jennifer Ramirez Mata, 30, was shot in the head and killed in Tyler, Tex., Tuesday morning, and her husband, 29-year-old Adrian Mata, was arrested. She leaves behind three children, ages 2, 6 and 11.
Phyllis Atkinson, 56, was shot and killed by her estranged husband in Chickasha, Okla., Tuesday afternoon. Patrick Atkinson, who had called his daughter and told her he was going to kill her mother, then shot and killed himself. The couple of 30 years was about to file for divorce following an affair.
Eva Garcia, 47, was shot and killed by 59-year-old Juan Hernandez, who then turned the gun on himself, at an east Dallas, Tex., nightclub Tuesday night. The couple, who had been in a relationship for about a year, were seen arguing before the shooting.
Harold Leibel, 64, was shot twice and killed in Douglas County, Nev., Sunday morning, and his wife, Tatiana Leibel, 50, was taken into custody.
A 15-year-old boy accidentally shot himself in Pine Hills, Fla., Tuesday afternoon. The victim originally told police he was shot by someone else, but then admitted he shot himself. Police have not said if he will face charges.
—WFTV
A 16-year-old boy was shot in the head and killed in a residential neighborhood in south Richmond, Va., early Tuesday. Police indicated that they may have a suspect.
A 17-year-old boy was shot in the knee in York, Pa., Monday afternoon. The victim told police that after an S.U.V. nearly struck a pedestrian, the driver and pedestrian began arguing and a gunshot rang out. Police have questions about the validity of the story, and some of the witnesses are not cooperating.
Torshon Megoogin, 17, was shot and killed near a high school in south Harvey, Ill., Sunday night. Police are looking at surveillance cameras near the school for possible suspects.
A woman in her 30s was shot three times and seriously wounded during a purse-snatching at a bus stop in Chicago Tuesday evening. No word on suspects. On Monday night, a 22-year-old man was wounded when someone fired into his apartment in the Trumbull Park neighborhood.
Two homeowners used guns to defend themselves against intruders in Detroit, Mich., early Saturday. In the first incident, a woman pulled her car into her garage when a man with a gun appeared. She dropped her keys on the ground as a distraction and then reached for her own gun, shooting and killing him. An hour and a half later, two men broke into a home in southwest Detroit armed with a tire iron, which they used to try to knock out the homeowner. The homeowner fired back with his own gun, shooting them both. One of the suspects, a 21-year-old man, was killed, and the other fled the scene. The shootings come less than a week after a woman opened fire on three teenagers who broke into her house while she was home with her children.
—WXYZ
A robbery suspect was shot and seriously wounded by a homeowner in Lake Stevens, Wash., Tuesday evening. The homeowner and a friend were in the garage when two masked men attempted to rob them at gunpoint. The homeowner’s friend pulled a gun out of his car and opened fire. The other suspect fled the scene.
Samuel Lee, 61, was shot and killed in the Eastlawn neighborhood of Wilmington, Del., Monday night. The victim was found collapsed on a sidewalk. Detectives canvassed the area looking for witnesses but have no suspect information.
A man was found shot in the head and killed in a parking lot across from a bar on the west side of Cleveland, Ohio, early Tuesday. Police said he may have been a patron at the bar earlier in the evening. Police have no suspect information.
A man in his 40s was shot and critically wounded while leaving his mother’s home in Riviera Beach, Fla., Tuesday night. A witness said a white car sped away after the shooting. No motive has been revealed and no arrests have been made.
—WPBF
A 27-year-old man was shot in the neck after an altercation with his mother’s boyfriend over a pit bull in Marshall County, Miss., Monday night. Investigators said the shooting appears to be accidental. No charges have been filed.
—WREG
Jimmy Emporellis, 34, was found shot to death in a car in Newark, N.J., Monday morning. Police believe the shooting was targeted.
A 22-year-old man was shot multiple times near Hilltop Park in the Bayview District of San Francisco, Calif., Monday night. The gunman drove up, shot the victim and sped off. He is being sought.
A man in his 30s was found with a fatal gunshot wound at a duplex in Kansas City, Kan., Tuesday morning. A neighbor said the victim was shot in the chest and had dried blood on his hands. Police have asked anyone with information to come forward.
—KSHB
Joshua A. Davis, 19, was shot and wounded at an apartment complex on the southeast side of Cedar Rapids, Iowa, early Tuesday. Police are interviewing witnesses.
A clerk at an Arlington, Tex., shoe store was shot and killed during a robbery Tuesday afternoon. The victim was in his early 20s. Police released surveillance video and photographs of the suspect, who is at large.
—WFAA
Steve Finkbeiner, 63, was killed and his wife, Constance Finkbeiner, 58, was critically wounded during a robbery at LaPlace Feed and Supply store in LaPlace, La., Tuesday afternoon. The victims owned the store. Deputies said a cash register and other items were taken, and leads are coming in.
—WDSU
Jack Dean Burns Jr., 39, was shot in the chest and killed in Forrest County, Miss., Tuesday afternoon. A suspect, Ronnie Pittman, was detained and then released pending actions from a grand jury.
—WDAM
Michael Leonard Tarman, 49, was shot and killed at a home in Lake Isabella, Calif., Tuesday morning. No other details have been released.
Two men, 21 and 30, were seriously injured in a shootout at Wedgewood Resort in Fairbanks, Alaska, early Tuesday. Two armed suspects entered an apartment with five people inside, one of whom was armed, prompting an exchange of gunfire. Police did not reveal a motive.
A woman was shot and wounded by someone who jumped out of a car and fired into a crowd in Bluefield, W.Va., Tuesday evening. Police believe the incident was sparked by an argument.
