article_title: 1965: Replacing American Jazzmen
normalized_article_title: 1965: replacing american jazzmen
text_content: PARIS — The Paris Musicians Union, with French government backing, has launched a campaign to replace many American jazz performers here with French musicians. The drive, aimed at foreigners in general but largely affecting American Negro musicians, is violently opposed by some of the owners of leading jazz clubs. Intended to provide permanent work for French players, it has already resulted in orchestra changes in some clubs and in the surveillance of nightspots by Ministry of Labor inspectors counting foreigners. The campaign would allow one or two foreign headliners to continue playing in each club. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, December 9, 1965

article_title: Reading The Times with Steve Coll
normalized_article_title: reading the times with steve coll
text_content:
Steve Coll is the Dean of the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University and a staff writer at The New Yorker.
Chinese Cruise Ship Sinks;
In Patriot Act Vote, Congress weighs Risk vs Liberty. Bribery Inquiry Drawing Closer to FIFA’s Chief.
Today’s top stories.
What disturbed you most?
We seem to be in a season of mass-drowning stories, and they are hard to read. I try not to skip over them though. This one from the Yangtze was tough — so vivid.
“Most of the passengers were 50 to 80 years old and had been traveling on a group tour.” Also, “The water where the boat sank is about 50 feet deep. Rescuers could hear the sounds of people trapped inside … ”
According to Peter Baker’s news analysis, a vast antiterrorism infrastructure will remain in place regardless of how the Senate votes on the Patriot Act. Does that seem right to you?
This campaign-season theater around expiry of the NSA’s domestic surveillance program has been frustrating. Even if you try to read the stories to filter out all the ephemeral politics, it’s hard to get a grip on what is really at issue — the structure of the surveillance regime itself.
If phone companies hold our metadata rather than the NSA, what difference will it make, given that the FISA courts are secret and not hard to please?
What use is actually being made of these powers by prosecutors, from day to day? Why are they being used in so many drug cases?
The Associated Press had an investigative story this week, with this lede: “The FBI is operating a small air force with scores of low-flying planes across the country carrying video and, at times, cellphone surveillance technology — all hidden behind fictitious companies that are fronts for the government, the Associated Press has learned.”
Huh? Maybe it’s time to give the black helicopter crowd down in Texas some credit.
Lindsey Graham enters the Presidential campaign. How closely are you following the endless campaign coverage?
I try to read all the horse race coverage every day, especially about the Republican primary, because it seems so open and fluid.
Lindsey Graham is a more-vivid-than-typical Washington figure. He’s known as a hawk but he does think independently. Name another Deep South Republican who is willing to price carbon to fight climate change. And he’s been constructive on immigration.
I hope he makes the cut for the early debates. I assume he has no chance to be nominated but he would liven things up, intelligently.
What story in today’s paper surprised you most?
I gave some dwell time to the story about the city of Paris starting to dismantle the love locks on the Pont des Arts. These are locks like you’d put on a gym locker that lovers place on the bridge as a symbol of their mutual devotion, tossing the key into the Seine.
I was in Paris recently and the locks are really, really ugly, a kind of vandalism. The craze to affix them on bridges in more and more cities feels like secular hysteria. But who are we to argue with people in love?
I enjoyed the reminder in this story of the pleasures of writing foreign correspondence, how you write through banal facts in a light feature-y way, testing what your editor will let into the paper.
Here is the 12th paragraph: “The locks still affixed to the bridge weigh an estimated 45 tons and will be kept in a city warehouse after they are removed … Some are likely to be melted down, meeting the same fate as the love of some who attached them to the bridge, but others may have a second life.” Ka-Ching.
Do you think the paper has successfully adapted to the culture of digital media?
It’s getting there, probably the best we have from a legacy newspaper.
Journalism has always been about fusing reporting, story and audience as technology changes — it’s been that way since the birth of radio.
I think The Times is well around the corner in publishing its distinctive journalism at a digital tempo and at experimenting with video, interactivity, computational journalism etc. The number of readers paying for digital subscriptions is encouraging for those of us who feel it is essential that The Times succeed.
The next hill is to figure out how to integrate coders with journalists and iterate continuously, while holding on to the core values. I’m clapping as hard as I can from the bleachers.
There’s an interesting Upshot piece today about college enrollment and income and reader’s thoughts on the correlation. Do you follow the Upshot with special interest?
I’m a big fan of Upshot. I spent a lot of time with this morning’s interactive graphic. It’s great that 70,000 readers tried to guess what such a policy nerd line would look like. That sort of online engagement, rewarded with a group shout-out on page three of the print edition, is what will create a digital community willing to pay premium prices for Times subscriptions, I would think (or hope).
How has the journalism school curriculum changed in recent years? Are J-school grads interested in different kinds of jobs than they were five years ago?
Yes we are trying to teach them how to get jobs at Upshot!
Seriously, the main change is to figure out how to integrate the teaching of statistics, coding, computation, data science, the reverse engineering of algorithms, etc. with hard core public interest journalism. The students want that sort of instruction, fortunately, and sign up for it in droves.
This year we also saw an out-of-the-blue doubling of applications for our investigative reporting and documentary filmmaking programs. Warms the heart, actually.
In the classroom I find that a lot of young journalists these days are very serious about their work. They want to do the math, go deep, work in long form.
Are there sections you read with special pleasure. Business? Sports? Science? Style?
I’m a devoted and undiscriminating sports fan and I think the Sports section is terrific these days, given its position against the New York tabloids, and given that it doesn’t have as many columns in the print edition to work with as I would like. Great to have Michael Powell’s shoe leather reporting and unpredictable voice in Sports now.
Are there columnists or critics you read with special interest?
Jim Stewart is a colleague at Columbia, and I’ve been a big fan ever since he used to clean my clock at The Wall Street Journal when I was a kid beat reporter covering securities fraud in the Drexel Burnham era. His Friday column in Business is best in class.
It will probably ensure she can never review one of my books again, but I should say that I’m also a huge Michiko Kakutani fan and read all of her reviews to the end. Her body of criticism about nonfiction since September 11 has no equal in its consistency and knowledge and I’m sure I would say that even if she didn’t appreciate my own work.
Do you read obituaries? Wedding announcements? Recipes?
Obituaries, always. Weddings, sometimes. Recipes, never. If you start a Thai take-in column, I’ll read that.
Anything in today’s paper that made you laugh?
Well, sardonically. I was very interested in the article about the Supreme Court decision in the case brought by the unsuccessful applicant to Abercrombie & Fitch, who sued for discrimination under the Civil Rights Act because her head scarf did not conform to the chain’s “classic East Coast collegiate style.”
Down in the story, Adam Liptak quotes an Abercrombie spokeswoman saying the company “has granted numerous religious accommodations when requested, including hijabs.” On the sales floor? Really?
And then the story quoted the plaintiff, Samantha Elauf: “I was born in the United States, and I thought I was the same as everyone else.”
She seems like a heroine, but that was inauthentic litigant-speak that made me harrumph. Apparently we need a Moshin Hamid short story to understand this case properly.

article_title: Should a Court Approve All Drone Strikes?
normalized_article_title: should a court approve all drone strikes
text_content:
In the area of armed conflict and war powers, a deliberative and serious Congress provides the best hope for promoting an effective and accountable executive.
Real Drone Strike Accountability Requires Political Checks
Neomi Rao, an associate professor at George Mason School of Law, previously served as associate counsel to President George W. Bush and as counsel to the Senate Judiciary Committee.
April 25, 2015
Whether comprised of Article III judges or constituted as a specialized court within the executive branch, a drone court raises serious constitutional problems. Designing a drone court in a manner that respects executive power over military operations as well as the independence of the judiciary would be difficult, if not impossible.
Moreover, from a public policy standpoint, it is unlikely that any drone court could address the concerns most frequently identified with targeted killings. Assuming for the sake of argument the validity of such concerns, these problems require political, not judicial, solutions.
Legal authority. Concerns have been raised about the president’s legal authority to engage in targeted killings, particularly against American citizens. A drone court does nothing to address this concern, as almost by definition, such a court would presume authority for lethal actions, evaluating and approving drone operations in specific circumstances. Substantive concerns about legal authority must be addressed by Congress in response to evolving security threats.
Accountability. Many have argued for greater transparency and oversight of the drone program. Yet the proceedings of drone courts will, by necessity, be secret. Public accountability is far more likely to come from Congress, which can oversee and review the targeted killing program in a manner that airs political concerns and respects the national security interests at stake.
Due process. Whether or not a drone court could provide due process depends on some understanding of what process is due in these circumstances. One should view with skepticism the Obama administration’s assertion, in a Department of Justice white paper, that due process is satisfied “where an informed, high-level official of the U.S. government has determined that the targeted individual poses an imminent threat.”
Nonetheless, a drone court will be unable to provide the type of due process usually associated with federal courts, in part because these would likely be ex parte hearings (in which the government appears without any adversarial process). Furthermore, experience (such as with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court) suggests secret and specialized courts face significant pressure to approve executive branch action. A judicial rubber stamp serves little purpose and may in fact undermine other forms of review and accountability.
The modern tendency is to view judicial checks as the primary, even exclusive, means of accountability. The Constitution, however, provides a variety of other checks. In the area of armed conflict and war powers, a deliberative and serious Congress provides the best hope for promoting an effective and accountable executive.

article_title: Daniel Davis - At War Blog
normalized_article_title: daniel davis - at war blog
text_content:
WASHINGTON – In October, the Army chief of staff, Gen. Ray Odierno, said that because of budget cuts, only two of the Army’s 42 combat brigades were ready for battle. In November, he warned members of the Senate Armed Services Committee that if the nation had to fight in the near term, “it is unlikely that the Army would be able to defeat an adversary quickly and decisively.”
Such warnings have become common around Washington in the wake of the deep cuts to the Pentagon budget this year, and the likelihood of another round of reductions next year. Last month, for instance, Republicans on the House Armed Services Committee warned that sequestration and other budget reductions “will bring our military to a force so small that a reassessment of our national security strategy will be required.”
But not everyone subscribes to the dire talk.
Last month, a group of retired senior-ranking officers argued before a packed audience at the Capitol Hill Club that despite the near certainty of shrinking military budgets, there are ways to trim the Defense Department’s spending without leaving the armed forces less-than-ready for combat. Their plan, they contend, could reduce the overall size of the military while actually increasing its combat power. And in doing so, it will support Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel’s call to revamp the military so that it remains sufficiently strong “under a cloud of budget restraints and uncertainty.”
Under the auspices of the Mitchell Institute, a nonprofit policy group founded by the Air Force Association, representatives of the Army, Air Force, and Navy presented a reorganization plan called the Macgregor Transformation Model. The plan is named after its architect, Douglas Macgregor, a retired Army colonel who is the author of several books on reorganizing the military and also a decorated combat veteran. Mr. Macgregor says his plan can produce an increase in combat capability, even with smaller budgets.
In an August essay in The National Interest, two retired officers, Adm. Mark Fitzgerald and Lt. Gen. David Deptula, along with a West Point history professor, Col. Gian Gentile, described the Macgregor Transformation Model as “a comprehensive Department of Defense-wide reform plan.” The core of that plan, they said, would be reorganizing the Army and Marines combat forces into “plug-and-play” modules — that is, battle groups capable of deploying immediately for just about any contingency, without support units. The authors said that the plan had been recently updated to account for the president’s 2012 decision to focus more resources on Asia, as well as to the reality of reduced federal budgets. The model, they concluded, “enables the Army in particular to reduce its overall size yet increase its combat power and strategic flexibility.”
At last month’s Capitol Hill Club event, Mr. Macgregor said those deployable units, which he called “Combat Groups,” would replace the current brigade-centric system of organizing forces now. Combat Groups would include the major elements of fighting forces — maneuver, strike, intelligence, surveillance, reconnaissance and sustainment units – making them self-sustaining forces that could still, as he put it, “punch above their weight.”
Mr. Macgregor also calls for shedding unnecessary or redundant personnel, reducing the layers of command while increasing the percentage of formations dedicated to war-fighting. He would, for instance, eliminate two-star division headquarters (whose function would be assumed by a smaller number of three-star Joint Task Force headquarters), reduce Combatant Commands to five from the current seven, and consolidate three different four-star headquarters (Training and Doctrine Command; Forces Command; and Army Materiel Command) into two three-star headquarters. The plan would also have a slightly smaller institutional Army than the one we have now by converting selected nondeploying positions from uniform to civilian jobs. All of these changes would be aimed at shortening the “tail” that supports the fighting force, while growing the “teeth.”
As a result, the plan’s supporters say, even at reduced budget levels, the Army would be able to field a greater number of combat battalions than it fielded in 2010, before reductions began. They estimated that even with 150,000 fewer troops, the reorganized Army could field an armored force containing almost 500 more tanks than during its peak year of 2010. A similar gain was projected for artillery, infantry, aviation and engineer units. All told, they say, the Army could reduce its current size of approximately 551,000 troops to as low as 420,000 without losing effectiveness. And more of those troops, they say, will be ready for deployment than is currently the case.
In his opening remarks at last month’s session, General Deptula, who is dean of the Mitchell Institute, said the Defense Department’s force structure had existed in its current form since 1942. “The time has arrived,” he said, “to reform and reorganize the Department of Defense toward joint operations in both word and deed. When a single service attempts to achieve war-fighting independence instead of embracing interdependence, jointness unravels and war-fighting effectiveness is reduced.”
Of course, a change as significant as the Macgregor model is likely to have its share of detractors both in the Pentagon and Congress. So far, the Pentagon seems to be silent on the plan. But two people in the audience at the Mitchell Institute event, one a liberal, the other a conservative, told me the ideas in the model are gaining traction among congressional staffers from both parties, spurred by the likelihood of new spending cuts.
“National defense isn’t a partisan issue,” said one. “It is an American issue.”
Daniel L. Davis is an active duty lieutenant colonel in the United States Army, stationed in the Washington, D.C. region. He has deployed into combat zones four times, and was awarded the Bronze Star for valor during Desert Storm and a Bronze Star in Afghanistan.
The views in this article are those of the author alone and do not represent the views of the Department of the Army or Department of Defense.

article_title: This Is What Happens When Modernity Fails All of Us
normalized_article_title: this is what happens when modernity fails all of us
text_content:
Modernity is failing non-Muslims too, and we must make the liberal promise a reality for all in order to render the appeal of radical utopias less attractive.
This Is What Happens When Modernity Fails All of Us
Muqtedar Khan teaches at the University of Delaware. He is a co-founder of the Delaware Council for Global and Muslim Affairs and is on Twitter.
Updated December 6, 2015, 11:09 PM
How can we wrap our minds around the perverse appeal of ISIS to youth growing up in modern, liberal and democratic societies of the West? What is it that compels a young woman in Paris or a well-established young professional in California to eschew the fruits of modernity and liberalism, to join a radical movement that is so brutal and inhuman that even Al Qaeda finds it repellent?
According to some, these youth have embraced an ideology, a radicalized interpretation of Islam, that teaches gratuitous violence against unbelievers. Their policy solutions — profiling Muslims, making a registry of all Muslim-American, closing mosques, etc. — seem as arbitrary as the violence.
Others argue that when Muslim youth in the West -- who are experiencing racism, Islamophobia and socio-economic marginalization or already alienated from their home communities -- see a movement that is fighting Western imperialism, such as support for Israel and invasion of Iraq, they run to join it in the hope that they will earn victory in this world and in the next.
Finding real policy solutions won't work until we subject modernity to a fundamental scrutiny. Why are youth in the West, where there are religious and political freedoms, equality and economic opportunity, turning away? The key question here is not what is the appeal of ISIS but rather why has the American dream and the promise of Western liberalism lost its appeal?
The answer is that modernity promises much more than it delivers and hence ultimately engenders disenchantment.
Muslims were told that if they embraced modernity they would become free and prosperous. But modernity has failed many Muslims in the Muslim World. It brought imperialism, occupation, wars, division and soul stifling oppression by home states and foreign powers. Today the most important element of modernity, the modern state, is crumbling across the Arab World, precipitating chaos and forcing Muslims to seek refuge abroad.
For Muslims in the West, unjust foreign policies of their new homes, persistent and virulent Islamophobia, state surveillance, discrimination and demonization can be at best alienating and at worst radicalizing. Perhaps it is those whom modernity has failed at home and abroad who are tempted by the fatal attraction of extremism.
But why Muslims only you might ask? My answer: Open your eyes and look, modernity is failing non-Muslims too. Egregious income inequalities, police brutality, rampant institutionalized racism, mass-killings, drugs, gang violence, sexual predatory behaviors, militarization of police, diminishing civil rights as the state becomes more intrusive and rising rhetoric of intolerance from mainstream politicians — they are symptoms of institutional failures, extremism and even domestic terrorism.
We can combat extremism only by recognizing and resisting it everywhere. But we must make the promise of modernity a reality for all in order to render the appeal of radical utopias less attractive.

article_title: China's Naval Chief Visited Disputed Islands in the South China Sea, Taiwan Says
normalized_article_title: china's naval chief visited disputed islands in the south china sea, taiwan says
text_content:
In the latest turn in the continuing territorial disputes in the South China Sea, Taiwan’s top intelligence official has said that the Chinese naval chief surveyed islands in the strategic waterway where China has been carrying out land reclamation work despite protests from other countries in the region, Hong Kong and Taiwanese news media reported on Thursday.
Speaking at a meeting in Taipei on Wednesday of the Foreign and Defense Committee of the Legislative Yuan, Lee Hsiang-chou, the director general of Taiwan’s National Security Bureau, said that Adm. Wu Shengli,
the commander of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army Navy, conducted a survey of five islands in the disputed Spratly archipelago last month. Calling the trip “unprecedented,” Mr. Lee said
that Admiral Wu had made the weeklong trip on a military ship in order to inspect the land reclamation work that China has been conducting on the islands in recent months, according to Takungpao,
a Hong Kong newspaper.
Takungpao, as well as the Taiwan-based United Daily News, also reported Mr. Lee as saying that President Xi Jinping of China had personally approved the reclamation work, which alarmed Southeast Asian nations that also claim sovereignty over the Spratly Island group when it was revealed earlier this year. Using a dredging vessel, China has been slowly turning several reefs into islands. Other claimants fear that Beijing wants to build military facilities on these land features, including an air base, in order to strengthen its claims.
The media reports did not identify all the South China Sea islands Mr. Lee was referring to, but, citing government reports, The Philippine Star reported last summer that China was carrying out reclamation activities on five reefs of the Spratly Islands that the Philippines also claims.
Mr. Lee’s comments, which were also reported on the website of the Chinese state-run newspaper Global Times but whose substance has not been formally confirmed by Beijing, are likely to set off new concerns about China’s territorial aspirations in the South China Sea.
At a regional security conference in May, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel of the United States leveled a rare, pointed criticism at China for what he called “destabilizing, unilateral actions” in asserting its territorial claims in the South China Sea, including “land reclamation activities at multiple locations.”
But it now appears that China has shrugged off these critiques and is intent on consolidating its territorial claims in the potentially resource-rich waters, through which around half of the world’s freight cargo passes.
China claims a large swath of the South China Sea, represented by a nine-dash line drawn from a Nationalist Chinese map in 1947. At its southernmost point, Beijing’s claim extends hundreds of miles from the Chinese mainland, nearly reaching the coastline of several Southeast Asian countries. The Philippines, Vietnam, Brunei and Malaysia each claim parts of the sea, and the claims of Taiwan, to which the Nationalist forces retreated after their defeat in the Chinese civil war in 1949, echo those of Beijing.
Mr. Lee’s comments came as Taipei is seeking to fortify its own claims in the sea with new military facilities. Reuters reported on Thursday that Taiwan is considering bolstering its military presence in the South China Sea by stationing ships permanently near disputed islands. The self-governing island, over which Beijing also claims sovereignty, is constructing a $100 million dollar port on Taiping Island in the Spratlys, where it already maintains an airstrip. Set to be completed next year, the port will allow the Taipei-controlled island to host 3,000-ton military and coast guard vessels.
At the meeting on Wednesday, Mr. Lee also said that Admiral Wu had overseen Chinese troop drills at Yongshu Island in the Spratly archipelago. Internationally known as Fiery Cross Reef, the site is about 740 nautical miles south of the Chinese mainland and serves as the administrative and military headquarters of China’s Spratly Island claims. It is home to about 100 troops.
Despite the criticism, it seems that China has continued to assert its claims through what some analysts have dubbed a “salami-slicing” approach, even as it calls for talks on joint development of the seas and says navigational safety will not be threatened. Earlier this year, the Chinese government said it would offer financial subsidies to fishermen who live in the Spratly and Paracel islands of the South China Sea.
Last spring, protests broke out in several cities in Vietnam after China deployed a deep-water oil-drilling platform near an island grouping off Vietnam’s coast that is controlled by China but claimed by Vietnam.

article_title: In a World Where China Sees Threats, Its Forces Make a Movie Critical of the U.S.
normalized_article_title: in a world where china sees threats, its forces make a movie critical of the u.s
text_content:
A conspiracy-minded 100-minute film produced by the Chinese military that was circulating widely on the Internet Thursday accuses the United States of trying to undermine the Communist Party’s control of the People’s Liberation Army and impose American values on China.
Among the American tactics decried in the film are military-to-military exchanges, which Washington has long promoted to improve communications in the event of a crisis. The video, complete with ominous soundtrack, warns instead that such visits are intended to corrupt Chinese officers.
The strikingly hard-line film, titled “Silent Contest” (较量无声), also takes aim at Western nongovernmental organizations, the American and British consulates in Hong Kong, and
prominent reformers inside China. It accuses Washington of sponsoring exiled minority leaders such as the Dalai Lama and the Uighur dissident Rebiya Kadeer.
It is not clear if the video was intentionally released online or somehow leaked, but it began disappearing from Chinese websites on Thursday night. Its heavy ideological content and propaganda style suggest it may have been produced to support the work of the military’s political commissars, who are charged with the ideological indoctrination of troops and maintaining their morale, discipline and loyalty. As such, the film appears to offer a remarkably straightforward glimpse into the Cold War mind-set of the Chinese military leadership, as well as the deep suspicions of the United States festering inside one of the most influential institutions in the Chinese political system.
Cutting from crude graphics of American dollar bills to standard shots of the Statue of Liberty to blurry footage of American leaders from George Washington to President Obama, the video bemoans the fall of the Soviet Union and warns that China faces a similar fate if it fails to counter Washington’s nefarious efforts to infiltrate Chinese society.
The General Staff Department of the People’s Liberation Army is listed as a producer of the film, along with the army’s National Defense University and the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences.
The university’s president, Wang Xibin, a lieutenant general, appears on camera describing how the United States grooms “friendly forces, so-called democratic forces,” inside China and on the “exterior goes against the party’s absolute control of the army.” He also criticizes visits by American and Chinese military officials to the other’s country, saying that the exchanges will increasingly be used by the United States for “infiltration.”
“We have to take careful precaution and look out for the smallest detail, and build a strong political and ideological line of defense,” General Wang says.
The United States has long urged reluctant Chinese leaders to increase the number of military exchanges, arguing that such visits yield transparency and trust. In recent months, several top Pentagon officers have traveled to China or hosted visits by their Chinese counterparts, a flurry that Washington has described as progress.
The version of the film available online Thursday was undated, but it contained footage of President Xi Jinping after he took office in March. It makes no mention of Edward J. Snowden, the former contractor with the National Security Agency whose leaks in June about the scale of Washington’s global surveillance presented the Chinese with a propaganda windfall.
The video singles out villains in both China and the United States.
In China, nearly a dozen people — scholars, lawyers, disgraced military personnel and dismissed journalists — are accused of having been compromised by the United States. In some cases, lines in their writings are shown and underlined for emphasis. Among those tarred are Mao Yushi, 84, a liberal economist who was awarded the Milton Friedman Prize for Advancing Liberty at a ceremony in Washington last year, and He Weifang, a prominent law professor at Peking University and an advocate for judicial reform.
On the American side, the video goes after nongovernmental organizations, including the Carter Center, the Asia Foundation, the International Republican Institute and the Ford Foundation. “Nongovernmental organizations are the soft tentacles of Western countries displaying the will of their nation,” the narrator intones. The Fulbright program, which has promoted cultural exchanges between the United States and other countries since the late 1940s, is called an instrument for “America’s cultural invasion.”
The video takes exception to local officials who visited the United States in 2004 to look at the election process as guests of the Carter Center, complaining that the participants were part of “a very meticulous plan” for what the Americans wanted to achieve in China. Sounding alarmed, the narrator points out that one official returned from the visit and wrote a blog post arguing that elections were the legitimate way for a government to gain power in a country.
The film depicts the United States and British consulates in Hong Kong as nests of spies, without actually using the word. “A lot of information suggests that the functions of the two consulates extend to more than what is described on paper,” the narrator says, noting that the consulates together employ more than 900 staff members and accusing them of supporting “subversive” pro-democracy movements in Hong Kong.
A spokesman for the American Embassy in Beijing had no comment on the film.

article_title: Debate Over Social Media Incitement as Flash Mobs Strike
normalized_article_title: debate over social media incitement as flash mobs strike
text_content:
Prime Minister David Cameron called it a “tough message,” but the harsh sentences being handed down by British courts in the wake of last week’s rioting have sparked an outcry, divided his governing coalition and raised questions about the proper response to incitement in the social media age.
The sentencing of two men to four years in prison for posting messages on Facebook in an attempt to organize disorder has drawn particular outrage among British politicians and the news media.
“This should be about restorative justice,” Tom Brake, a Liberal Democrat member of Parliament, said on BBC television, The Guardian reported. “It should not be about retribution.” The Liberal Democrats are the Conservatives’ partners in the coalition government.
According to British news reports, Jordan Blackshaw, 20, and Perry Sutcliffe-Keenan, 22, admitted trying to organize disorder over Facebook, but said they were unsuccessful. Their lawyer told the BBC that it had started as a joke and that the family was “shocked by the sentence.”
A prominent British lawyer called a four-year sentence for posting messages online “disproportionate,” and along with Mr. Cameron’s call for limitations on social media seemed to echo — albeit faintly — Arab regimes that have harshly punished social media “misuse.”
Of course, there is a wide gulf between a government’s legitimate interest in preventing criminality and a despot’s attempt to thwart opposition by shutting down their channels of communication. But some have objected to the proposed technology clampdown, questioning the notion that social media played a significant part in the days of unrest and looting that convulsed London and several other British cities. Few messages posted to public sites like Twitter and Facebook have surfaced directly connected to violence, which appears to have been organized primarily via text message and private networks like BlackBerry’s BBM service.
Here’s my question. Yes, communication infrastructure can be influential in unrest. Is there any evidence it was for #ukriots?
Judicial advocates also objected to the stiff punishments, which were handed out in many cases to first-time offenders. “When people get caught up and act out of character, in a similar way, there is a danger that the courts themselves may get caught up in a different kind of collective hysteria,” Paul Mendelle, former chairman of the Criminal Bar Association, told the BBC. “In purporting to reflect the public mood,” he said, courts “actually go over the top and hand out sentences which are too long and too harsh.”
In an interview with the French magazine Les Inrockuptibles, a Labour Party member accused Mr. Cameron of fundamentally misunderstanding new technology, seeing social media sites like Twitter and Facebook and instant message services like BlackBerry’s BBM only as organizing tools for mayhem. “His reaction shows that he has trouble distinguishing the message from the medium,” the member, Chi Onwurah, said.
The same message can be heard from social media observers and others online who, in an appropriation of the National Rifle Association’s favorite saying, have said that it’s the people, not the social media platforms, doing the organizing.
Social media doesn’t organize riots. People organize riots.
However, it’s a point Mr. Cameron would likely endorse as it seems to underscore the importance of punishing those individual people who use social media in violation of the law. (Incitement — even on social media — is illegal in Britain, as The Lede has written before.)
While many focused on punishments, Cory Doctrow, a Canadian journalist and the editor of Boing Boing, wrote in The Guardian of the failure of Britain’s widespread closed-circuit cameras to prevent mobs from gathering and committing crimes to begin with.
But for me, the use of BlackBerrys in organizing riots (if “organise” is the correct verb here) is just a sideshow. Though as a Canadian, I’m fascinated to see that our national technology success story, the businesslike BlackBerry, has now enduringly entered pop culture’s lexicon as the tool of choice for disaffected and violent youth.
The real story for me is about surveillance, and not the mere use of CCTV footage to apprehend rioters after the fact. It’s about the total failure of CCTV to deter people from committing crimes in the first place.
Indeed, cameras that captured brazen criminality, including a vehicular attack on London police, have been used to try to apprehend offenders but certainly did not stop the crimes from occurring.
Similarly, in Maryland, the police published video of a brazen “flash mob” looting a local 7-Eleven.
CNN reported that police believe the group of at least 28 people was organized online. The cameras were no deterrent, but are being used to identify suspects. “We’re getting a lot of response from sources in the community who have seen the video, who are concerned, and are calling police with tips,” Capt. Paul Starks told CNN.
One preventative measure that does appear, for the moment, to be working against criminal gangs organized online: a curfew in Philadelphia meant to halt a wave of flash mobs in the city’s center.
None were reported over the past weekend, The Philadelphia Inquirer reported, though just outside of it, a girl who had attended an antiviolence party was stabbed.

article_title: Blood, Sweat and Trophies
normalized_article_title: blood, sweat and trophies
text_content:
Related
Man United!
By TIM ADAMS
Million dollar players come and go, but the success of the world’s greatest sports club is the work of Sir Alex Ferguson, 69, who, after a quarter century, is not going anywhere. Meet the man in Man United. More…
Even the hard men of Manchester United scrub up nicely for a fashion shoot in T: The New York Times Style Magazine. But behind every renowned player are years of blood, sweat and tears in training. United’s history is a blend of talents hired from around the globe, joined with schoolboys raised to play with the attacking brio that characterizes the team.
The work toward this end takes place in secret at the Carrington training complex on the outskirts of Manchester. It is entered by a single-track road and guarded day and night by electronic surveillance, high wire fencing and 30,000 trees. The locals know it as “Fortress Carrington.” David Sebbah, T’s creative director, was allowed inside, as he traveled the globe with the photographer Max Vadukul in pursuit of portraits of the players and coaches.
Housed inside two hangar-like buildings, the facility serves as a living museum to players past and present. They are the chosen ones, set on course by the club manager Matt Busby, between 1945 and 1971, and by Alex Ferguson, his successor since November 1986. Both are Scots, and both were knighted by the British monarch.
Busby oversaw the rebuilding of United’s Old Trafford stadium into a modern arena that attracts crowds up to 76,000 strong. In contrast, he established a training setup in a place known as the Cliff, away from the public glare and the spying of opponents. Busby’s greatest triumph was to build it all from the ground up, and then rebuild it again after his team, the Busby Babes, was destroyed in a plane crash that almost killed him.
Ferguson is imbued with a similar, if more aggressive, spirit, and works from dawn to dusk at Carrington, the “new” training camp that opened 11 years ago. Surrounded by 1.5 miles of fencing, entered by players in their Ferraris and by the 200 employees who teach, care for and watch over them, Carrington is the laboratory striving to maintain traditions.
The facility has a medical center, lounges, study rooms, offices, squash courts, a basketball area, rehabilitation facilities and even the Manchester United TV studio. Old Trafford may be “The Theatre of Dreams” where championships are won, but Carrington, part farm and part workhouse, is the stealth enabler behind those dreams. No one enters Carrington without the permission of Sir Alex. And no one leaves until they pass his tests of workmanship or are shown the exit.

article_title: Taking a Gander at the Peepers in Union Square Park
normalized_article_title: taking a gander at the peepers in union square park
text_content:
Very little happens in Union Square that escapes the notice of a man known as Normal Bob Smith, a longtime park fixture who chronicles its characters on the “Amazing Strangers” portion of his Web site.
One of his main genres of park characters is the peeper. Normal Bob, whose given name is Bob Hain, says peepers are a constant presence in the south section of the park, where they prey on women wearing skirts who sit on the sets of steps along 14th Street.
For years, Mr. Hain, 42, a graphic artist who lives in Bushwick, has been peeping at the peepers: shooting pictures and video footage of the surreptitious gawkers to post on his site, along with detailed analyses of the strategies they use to steal glances while seeming to blend in with pedestrians.
Several months ago, Mr. Hain’s collection of peeper chronicles caught the attention of producers from “Inside Edition,” and now the program is broadcasting an investigation of the peepers on Monday at noon on WNYW, Channel 5, in New York City.
In August, “Inside Edition” sent a team of people with hidden cameras to stake out the regular peeping sections. They shot footage of a handful of men who looked — often for hours at a time — under the skirts of women on the steps, said Larry Posner, a producer of the segment.
“It was shocking to learn how prevalent it was in the park,” Mr. Posner said. “We had heard about it, but to see it day in and day out, our staffers were equally disgusted.”
One member of the team shot footage from the second-story eating area of the Whole Foods that overlooks the park on 14th Street. Another videotaped the peepers head-on, from a vantage point past the women, with a third staff member roaming behind the peepers, to see if they were taking pictures of the women — many were, Mr. Posner said. Hidden cameras were used to film the segment.
The program also put two young female researchers on the steps dressed in short skirts — with shorts underneath — and using cameras tucked in their purses to shoot the peepers.
“I think people will watch and say, ‘I can’t believe this is going on,’ ” Mr. Posner said. “Unless the girls are really looking for it, they’d never know.”
Mr. Posner said the team did not contact the police about the peepers they investigated, but he added, “We hope by showing this, we’ll bring awareness to this issue and action will be taken.”
Mr. Posner said he or the on-air correspondent for the segment, Lisa Guerrero, would typically confront a peeper once it was established that the person was photographing women. The segment shows them confronting three men on-camera, each of whom denied he was peeping, he said.
Mr. Posner said his research of court papers showed two arrests in recent months for illegal surveillance in the Union Square area.
Peeper arrests are rare in New York City public spaces because simply trying to look under the skirts of women is not a crime. Voyeurism is illegal when the subject is unaware and the image is recorded on camera.
In 2007, Councilman Peter F. Vallone Jr. introduced a bill in the City Council that would prohibit peeping in public places such as parks and subways, but civil rights groups have objected to such laws.
“Inside Edition” came away with plenty of footage of Mr. Hain’s regular peepers, including Preppy Peeper (who dresses in preppy clothes) and Portrait Peeper (he leers while pretending to paint portraits).
Mr. Hain helped producers identify the peeping styles, how to distinguish “tandem-style peeping,” for instance, from “front row peeping.” He has been holding forth on these and other details of the peepers on the “Methods of a Peeper” videos — “the behavior and science behind the Union Square Peeper” — on his site, laying out various practices and providing detailed diagrams of peeper strategies and preferred sight lines.
Last Thursday, Mr. Hain was in his usual spot in the park, on the steps near 14th Street and Park Avenue. He pointed out the current group of peepers in front of him: a man in work boots and a polo shirt; another man who had a mullet haircut and was wearing a dark T-shirt; and a short man wearing a white T shirt.
“These guys are regulars,” Mr. Hain said. “The guy in the polo shirt is pretending to be on the phone — he’ll stand like that for hours. The short guy is Mini-Peeper. For some reason, because of his size, he doesn’t get noticed as easily and gets real close.”

article_title: Housing Project Feud Cited in Killing of Basketball Star
normalized_article_title: housing project feud cited in killing of basketball star
text_content:
As soon as Tayshana Murphy, 18, was shot early Sunday in the Grant Houses, a public housing project in Morningside Heights, Manhattan, her friends and neighbors declared that they knew, immediately, who had killed her.
“Manhattanville killed her, it’s a fact,” said Calvin Spencer, 30, who lives in the same building as Ms. Murphy did: 3170 Broadway at West 125th Street, where Morningside Heights meets West Harlem.
Mr. Spencer was referring to the Manhattanville Houses, another public housing complex just across 125th Street from the Grant Houses. Residents of both housing complexes said there had been a running feud between the projects for years, and that fights among young residents had increased before the shooting.
“It’s a senseless beef and it goes back before I was born,” Mr. Spencer said. “I remember growing up with it in the ’90s. Things were escalating the last couple weeks and these guys came here to hurt a Grant person, didn’t matter who it was. And now this is going to make it worse.”
Police officials also said the shooting might have been connected to the dispute between the projects.
“It’s stupid stuff; these two groups don’t even know each other,” said Krisy Reyes, 18, a friend of Ms. Murphy’s. “All they knew was, ‘We’re Manhattanville, they’re Grant. So they’re the enemy.’”
Manny Cerrutty, 42, another longtime resident of the Grant Houses, stared at the makeshift shrine Ms. Murphy’s friends had made, with hundreds of handwritten messages scrawled on a bedsheet duct-taped to the building’s facade. On the ground were more than 100 candles, and empty bottles of liquor, apparently consumed in tribute.
“They killed Grant’s star,” Mr. Cerrutty said. “It’s all going to start back up now.”
Several teenagers sitting on a railing nearby, agreed, and perhaps indulged in a bit of bravado.
“There’s going to be bodies dropping in the ‘Ville now, for real,” one said, referring to the Manhattanville Houses.
Ms. Murphy, who was known as Chicken, lived in a 15th-floor apartment at 3170 Broadway. She moved to the Grant Houses five years ago with her mother and two brothers.
There, she developed into a high school basketball star, playing competitive games on the projects’ courts and in tournaments in summer. She also practiced her dribbling incessantly in front of the building, in between dancing and holding court among groups of friends.
On Sunday, police officials and neighbors said, Ms. Murphy was in a group of young people outside the Grant Houses when some men walked up to them on a short walkway from Broadway. The Grant group scattered and Ms. Murphy fled into her building and ran up the stairs. She was shot several times in a stairwell on a fourth-floor landing; her blood remained on the wall on Wednesday. Nearby walls were covered with graffiti tributes.
The police said three men were captured on surveillance cameras approaching Ms. Murphy’s building carrying guns. On Tuesday, the police announced that one of them, Terique Collins, 24, had been arrested in the Manhattanville Houses and charged with weapons possession. The police identified the other two suspects as Tyshawn Brockington, 21, and Robert Cartagena, 20, but did not provide information on Wednesday about where they lived.
Ms. Murphy began playing basketball at age 5 – usually with boys – while growing up in the Queensbridge Houses in Long Island City, Queens. She was ranked on an ESPN Web site as the nation’s 16th-best point guard in her class, and was starting her senior year at Murry Bergtraum High School for Business Careers, a New York City basketball powerhouse.
Ms. Murphy was known for her ball-handling and her ability to drive hard to the hoop, but she also enjoyed a sometimes raucous social life outside her building, friends said.
Some of Ms. Murphy’s friends insisted that she was not involved in any rivalry between the projects. But others said that she, or her 17-year-old brother, known as Bam-Bam – might have been involved in a fight the night before the shooting. (Ms. Murphy and her brother were strikingly similar in appearance.)
On Saturday night, some said, a young man from the Manhattanville Houses was beaten and slammed over the head with a bicycle outside the C-Town supermarket, on 125th Street on the edge of the Grant Houses. Her killing, several hours later, was retribution, they said.
Feuds between nearby housing projects are not uncommon. There have been longstanding, recurring rivalries among complexes in the Rockaways, including Beach 41st Street Houses, the Ocean Bay Houses and Ocean Village.
“It’s common, the feuds, but Chicken was only involved in basketball, nothing else,” said Zanobia Rivera, 18, who described herself as Ms. Murphy’s girlfriend.
Ms. Rivera, a senior at the Global Learning Collective school in Manhattan, was standing by the shrine for Ms. Murphy, clutching a pair of her red basketball shorts.
In the Manhattanville Houses, a young couple pushing their baby in a stroller said there had been constant fights between groups of young men from the two projects in recent weeks.
“They learn this stupidity at a young age,” said the mother, who would not give her name for fear of retribution. “My little brother just started seventh grade at the local school, which has mostly Manhattanville kids. They’ve already started bullying him, asking him, ‘You from Grant, huh? You from Grant?’ Where do they learn this?”
Near the shrine, Mr. Spencer, a fledgling rapper known as Babyface, said, “The only thing we can do is try to stop the violence because violence ain’t going to bring Chicken back.”

article_title: Video Shows Washington Monument During Earthquake
normalized_article_title: video shows washington monument during earthquake
text_content:
The National Park Service said Monday that the Washington Monument would remain closed indefinitely because of damage sustained in a 5.8-magnitude earthquake that rattled the East Coast in August.
In this surveillance video, released by the Park Service on Monday, you get an idea why. As the camera shakes and rattles, dust and debris falls from overhead and frightened tourists scramble down the stairs.
On Tuesday, engineers will rappel down the 555-foot obelisk to better assess the damage to the world’s tallest stone structure. According to The Washington Post,
a mountaineering and rope-rigging ranger, Brandon Latham, from Denali National Park in Alaska, will help the engineers make their way down the monument safely.
The Associated Press reported that a crack four feet long and one inch wide was found the day of the quake, and that in some areas, you can see through the crevices in the stone all the way to outside. So far, The A.P. said, the Park Service has spent more than $200,000 inspecting the damage.

article_title: TV Chat: Ask the Critics
normalized_article_title: tv chat: ask the critics
text_content:
Now that viewers have gotten a look at most of the new shows this season, the fall television picture is becoming clearer: sitcoms like “New Girl” (with Zooey Deschanel) and “2 Broke Girls” (with Kat Dennings) have gotten votes of confidence, Tim Allen’s “Last Man Standing” earned a spot in the Top 30, while “H8R,” “Free Agents” and “How to Be a Gentleman” are out or on their way. Did these shows deserve their fates, for better or worse? Speaking of comedies, HBO unveiled “Enlightened” and came back with a new season of “Bored to Death” and a male breast-feeding scene. Has HBO finally gone too far? The television critics Mike Hale and Neil Genzlinger have posted answers to your questions and comments.
Homeland with time brought up to date,
Owes to Manchurian candidate?
Is the theme tired,
And hardly inspired?
Production and cast are first rate.
— Larry Eisenberg, New York City
Neil Genzlinger: Picture Carrie enjoying a shower,
When who should walk in but Jack Bauer?
He’s been unemployed,
Now he’s newly deployed
For a terror-fighting cross-over hour.
Mike Hale: I thought about answering in limerick form, but I can’t come up with any rhymes for Sinatra or Frankenheimer. I certainly don’t hold it against “Homeland” that it owes a debt to “The Manchurian Candidate” — it’s consciously drawing parallels between our current political and cultural situation and the early days of the Cold War, something that one of its consulting producers, Henry Bromell, is very adept at. And there are plenty of differences in the way the story is being told. I think the big question is how long they can string out the mystery regarding the Damian Lewis character’s real feelings without having it get silly.
I thought the pilot of ‘New Girl’ was one of the worst things I’ve ever seen on TV. I continued to watch because of the wide acclaim and the subsequent episodes were better; but I’m still not convinced. I like Zooey Deschanel and the basic premise of the show; but I really can’t embrace the other actors and/or their characters. To say they are two-dimensional is probably being too complimentary. And the ‘jokes’ are mostly very tired re-treads. — Larry, The Fifth Circle
Neil Genzlinger: Yes, there’s certainly a lot of retreading going around this fall, especially in the comedies. And a lot of two-dimensionality. I think you’ve hit on something. The great comedies of the past had characters who were well-enough developed that they could take a detour away from slapstick and into something serious, and the audience would follow. The Edith Bunker cancer episode of “All in the Family,” for instance. Hard to imagine most of the fall newcomers pulling that off, though of course it’s early yet.
Mike Hale: Oh, there have been much worse things on television than the “New Girl” pilot. That said, I agree with your basic premise and have been saying so every chance I get: there’s nothing to the show beyond Zooey Deschanel’s charm and timing, and if they don’t do something about that it’s going to get old really fast. I’ve had this discussion face to face several times — when I tell people, look, the writing is flat and none of the three guys is funny, they just plant their feet and shake their heads, because they’re so desperate to like the show.
I’ve been watching The New Girl, 2 Broke Girls, and I watched Last Man Standing last night. The New Girl is a little wanna-be Tina Fey and trite but it’s cute. Last Man Standing was exactly what you expect: Home Improvement done over (thus entertaining). … It’s sad that Kat Dennings (who is hilarious) is on a show that has such a stereotypical asian character, pretty offensive- resembling Long Duck Dong from Sixteen Candles (when it was still okay to not be at least a little bit PC). It’s too bad because the show had a lot of potential! — Stephanie, Minneapolis
Mike Hale: This is the price we pay for not protesting the character Ken Jeong plays in the “Hangover” movies and, to a lesser extent, his Senor Chang in “Community.” As you laugh, so shall you reap.
Neil Genzlinger: Can’t go along with your suggestion that “Last Man Standing” is entertaining. Or that it’s “Home Improvement” done over. It’s a sort of reverse-“Terra Nova” of “Home Improvement”: some of the more Neanderthalic elements of that ancient show (which were funny in the original context) have been transplanted into the now, but somehow the wit and chemistry between cast members did not make it through the portal.
NBC does not seem to be improving in the wake of the Comcast takeover. THE PLAYBOY CLUB and FREE AGENTS have already bitten the dust, and though they’ve just ordered more scripts for both PRIME SUSPECT and HARRY’S LAW, neither is exactly blowing the roof off the ratings. Thoughts? — MockingbirdGirl, USA
Mike Hale: It’s worth remembering that Robert Greenblatt didn’t take over as head of entertainment programming for NBC until March, after the merger had been completed, by which time it was too late for him to be involved in developing any of this fall’s shows. His imprint won’t really be seen until next year. And I don’t think the season will be a complete loss: “Prime Suspect” may turn out to be a pretty good show. Whether the ratings will reflect that, who knows. We’re just critics.
Neil Genzlinger: I agree with Mike that “Prime Suspect” is becoming a pretty good show now that it’s slowly moving past the creaky old woman-in-a-man’s-world stuff. I could see Maria Bello getting an Emmy nomination if the show sticks around. She was pretty funny in the most recent episode, self-consciously trying to soften her rough edges.
Considering what HBO has served up over the years, surely you’re joking about male breast-feeding being “too far”. — BooksAboutMovies, Toronto, Ontario
Mike Hale: I think we were joking about that. It’s been a few weeks since I watched those “Bored to Death” episodes, but if I’m remembering correctly, you don’t actually see Zach Galifianakis’s nipples, or at least you don’t see them in the vicinity of the baby. It’s probably more subversive when his character, Ray, goes to Prospect Park and tries to talk mothers there into nursing the baby for him.
Neil Genzlinger: Um, yes, we’re joking about the shocking, SHOCKING! male breast-feeding scene. But I can spin a serious point out of that if you want. Here’s why “Bored to Death” and shows like “The League” and “It’s Always Sunny in Philadelphia” on FX are funny where so many of new prime-time comedies aren’t. When they do something absurdly outrageous — male breast-feeding, painting a swastika on your street so the city will finally come fill in that pothole at the end of your driveway in order to cover up the graffiti (a joke from “The League”) — they’re doing it organically, and with their audience as co-conspirators. Whereas when Whitney or Kat or whoever on the new shows makes some penis reference, it’s with a big neon sign: “Hey, I just said ‘penis’ on prime-time television! Aren’t I cutting-edge?”
What series do you sense may be on its last legs excluding those already being promoted as the last season (e.g., Desperate Housewives)? What is the one show no one’s watching and should? — BodegaVendetta, NYC
Mike Hale: This may be too easy of an answer, but it looks like it’s going to be an uphill climb for “Law & Order: SVU” without Christopher Meloni and with less of Mariska Hargitay (if that actually happens). On your second question, I think there are two shows up against each other on Friday nights that deserve bigger audiences than they have, though both have done well enough to ensure their continued survival: “Fringe” on Fox and “Supernatural” on CW. They’re pigeonholed as shows for sci-fi/fantasy geeks, but they’re better than a lot of crime or medical or family dramas that get more viewers.
Neil Genzlinger: Maybe this is just wishful thinking on my part, but, on the reality side, it feels as if some shows that have wrung their gimmicks dry ought to die soon, just on general principles. “Jersey Shore,” for instance. “Project Runway.” Probably both will live forever, because they have an established audience that seems unable to get enough of what they do, but I can’t watch them anymore; they just feel to me as if they’ve shown all their tricks. Yeah, I know, heresy. Here’s another: “Late Show With David Letterman” has been feeling spent to me for awhile now. Maybe it’s time for someone new there?
I’ll stay on the reality side for Part 2 of the question: I continue to be a fan of “The Sing-Off” on NBC and can’t understand why so few people watch it while so many were willing to sit through the torture that was the first few weeks of “The X Factor.” I guess some people still get a charge out of the phony audition drama and deliberately awful performances that “The X Factor” trafficked in during its first weeks, but to me those audition episodes just seemed like one long cliche. (Now that the show has finally gotten through all that and is down to the real singers, though, I’m actually looking forward to it, and was a bit bummed when it was bumped Wednesday night by baseball.) If your interest is just in the singing, the stuff being done on “The Sing-Off” — on which NBC risked a big chunk of its Monday night this season — is much better and more sophisticated than what “The X Factor” serves up.
How do you feel about the increasing number of laugh-less “dramedies” on cable — shows that arguably contain few if any genuine jokes? t’s as if awkward squirming has replaced actual laughter as the intention for these series, and ‘Enlightened’ is yet another entry into a category filled with recent (or not so recent) arrivals like “Wilfred,” “Louie,” “How to Make It in America,” “Weeds”, “Big C”, “Web Therapy,” etc. Personally, I like many of the shows I’ve listed, but they’re a far cry from the zany, classic(al) comedies that I grew up with. — MC, Los Angeles
Mike Hale: I like some of them too — I think “Louie” is one of the best shows on TV, and “Weeds” used to be pretty good. You may unconsciously be falling into the same way of thinking as the television academy, which puts all half-hour shows in the “comedy” category at the Emmys, regardless of their content. There’s nothing that says a show should be funny — or funny ha-ha, in any case — just because it’s a half-hour long.
Neil Genzlinger: The laughless comedy — an interesting phenomenon indeed. For shows like that, it’s all about pitch. I couldn’t quite latch onto “Enlightened,” though perhaps some people did. I got what it was aiming for, just didn’t care. Whereas I love “Wilfred” and “Web Therapy” and some of the others. It’s certainly a riskier type of comedy than the old laugh-track sitcom, so kudos to those who are offering these shows.
I’ve only seen Last Man Standing and Suburgatory and they are unwatchable. I’m scared to check out the others. What gives? Why are these alleged comedies so lame? Seriously. — Ha, Boston
Mike Hale: And this is where we point out that the premiere of “Last Man Standing” drew nearly 13 million viewers at 8 p.m., with no lead-in, making it one of the strongest debuts of the new season. And it was especially strong in the 18-to-49 demographic. And viewership went up during the second half of the hourlong episode. So for now, at least, it’s lame all the way to the bank.
Neil Genzlinger: How this stuff gets on the air remains a mystery, but I suspect were we to go back through television coverage of the last 40 years, we’d find that it’s an annual mystery: every season, some clunkers inexplicably get onto the schedule. I also bet we’d find that annually there’s at least one show that is universally panned and yet draws an audience. Beats me why so many people watched “Last Man Standing,” but a lot of things that “so many people” do bewilder me — going to karaoke clubs, texting photos of their private parts, drinking water from a plastic bottle. I’m the problem; I realize that.
Why is it that the networks–through the long development process and their summer-long promotion of shows like Playboy Club–can’t (or won’t?) see what is obvious to most viewers after one or two episodes? (That they are terrible). — Andrew, New York
Mike Hale: A lot of terrible shows do fine. Is “Two and a Half Men” better than “The Playboy Club”? No, it’s worse. Among the new-season dramas, are “Unforgettable” or “Terra Nova” better than “The Playboy Club”? Not by a whole lot, but they’re both getting decent ratings. It’s a terribly subjective business, and thank God for that, or we wouldn’t have anything to write about.
Neil Genzlinger: Whatever the process is, it certainly seems danged inefficient here in the age when, on a talent-competition show, the national preference can quickly be determined with a simple telephone poll. Gotta be a way to float an advance look at a show and ask the country, “You wanna see any more of this?” Yeah, I know, it’s expensive to make even a trailer for a new show. But still. It feels a bit like book publishing: Many books are still produced via a laborious publishing process that takes a year or more, but suddenly here we are in the age of e-readers and insta-books.
I was disappointed in Harry’s Law after the first episode but I stuck with it. The show seems to be smartly written, though a few of the sub plots are a bit of a drag. Last night it was a bummer to see one of the last of the original quirky cast members leave. Have you changed your opinion of the show recently? — Barry, Vermont
Neil Genzlinger: “Harry’s Law” certainly seems adrift somehow. I think it would be in danger of cancellation if it were on another network. NBC may need to keep it around just because of the other shows it has that are failing.
For some reason, to me, DANCING WITH THE STARS is feeling like a non-event, but what’s clear is that the fan-base for pretty, sexy talented, musically gifted performers (like Chynna Phillips, whose upcoming Wilson Phillips reality show I’m excited about) aren’t sending people to the phone lines. No one’s voting against them, I think, but people are deliberately voting for the quirky (and I count Ricki Lake as quirky). Do you have any predictions as to whether this season’s demographic shift for the show is affecting it permanently, or is it just a one-time casting blip? — Freddie, New York City
Neil Genzlinger: “Dancing With the Stars” feels “over” to me. There; I said it.
I enjoy sf and horror. I did not enjoy the family friendly dino antics of Terra Nova. American Horror Story is another story. Delightfully creepy. Sick in a most entertaining fashion. — jjo, St. Pete, Fl.
American Horror Story, as uneven as it might be, seems to be one of the only shows playing with narrative and trying new things in storytelling. Think it will last? — Aaron, NYC
Mike Hale: I think it has a good chance, though you have to wonder what the budget is with all those well-known actors in the cast. (I assume Jessica Lange isn’t working for scale.) It benefits from the lower ratings expectations of cable, but on the other hand FX hasn’t been shy when it came to canceling prominent new dramas like “Terriers” and “Lights Out.” I gave “American Horror Story” a mixed review, tending toward negative, but I want to like it, because it’s different and because I like watching Connie Britton and Denis O’Hare and Ms. Lange. I’m hoping it finds its stride.
Neil Genzlinger: Interesting point that I hadn’t registered before: With the new season we’re getting the two extremes of sci-fi, the PG version and the almost-R version. I’ve heard a number of people say they’re disappointed in “Terra Nova,” but I have to confess I rather liked the most recent episode — pretty good plot premise, well-executed. For those who missed it, the Novians, or whatever they’re called, were being afflicted by a virus that ate their memories and caused them to revert to an earlier point in their lives. As I was watching, I was also toggling back and forth to “The Sing-Off,” where the groups were doing their own bit of time-regression: they were assigned to sing songs from the ’60s.
The only new show i’m making a point to watch is Revenge which is just escapist, nighttime soapy fun. I wish A Gifted Man was better – the casting is great but the stories are falling flat for me. — bridget212323, Los Angeles
Neil Genzlinger: I’m with you, Bridget: “Revenge” has become my favorite among the new shows. Yeah, it’s soap-opera silly, but Emily VanCamp is beguiling (someone explain to me why she’s billed below Madeleine Stowe?), and as it goes along it’s developing some nice subplots. Nolan Ross (Gabriel Mann), Emily/Amanda’s confidant, may be the most interesting character on any of the new shows.
Mike and Neil, looks like another poor start for NBC. Do they have anything more promising in the pipeline? And how patient will new overlords, Comcast, be with their in/near cellar-dwelling? CBS programming seems so tired, even with new offerings, yet they remain on top. This must be totally frustrating for programming heads at NBC, and elsewhere. What does NBC have to do to get back viewers? Thanks for your insights. — janwell, Wellesley, MA
Mike Hale: It’s interesting that you mention the pipeline, because they have in fact saved a couple of their more interesting drama pilots for midseason: the crime drama “Awake” — a fractured-reality show somewhat along the lines of “Life on Mars,” this one starring Jason Isaacs — and the behind-the-scenes-of-a-Broadway-musical show “Smash,” with Debra Messing among many others. It’s too early to say anything about them from a critical standpoint, but I think it’s safe to say that “Smash” will get a lot of attention, at least in New York.

article_title: Someone Is Stealing Purses at Katz's Deli
normalized_article_title: someone is stealing purses at katz's deli
text_content:
If she had simply had her hand in the pickle jar at one place — or if she had stuck a finger in the maple-butter dish at the other — this would be a different story, and probably more delectable.
But the police say the woman reached for something else at Katz’s Delicatessen and Clinton Street Baking Company, both on the Lower East Side: customers’ pocketbooks.
Four times in the last five months, the police say, the woman grabbed a purse that had been slung over the back of a chair occupied by a customer — three times at Katz’s, which is large and usually crowded, and the other time at Clinton Street Baking Company, which is small and also usually crowded.
The police, seeking tips from the public, released a video they said was recorded at Katz’s on Sept. 30, which caught the woman in the act at 3:30 p.m. The police described her as a black woman who was between ages 40 and 50. She also stole pocketbooks at Katz’s, on Houston and Ludlow Streets, on May 1 and May 28, the police said, and on June 17 at Clinton Street Baking Company, at 4 Clinton Street.
DeDe Lahman, an owner of Clinton Street Baking Company, said there had been another incident on Sept. 20 not mentioned in an alert from the police. “Both times, she came in, cased the place, went to the bathroom and when she came out, grabbed a purse,” Ms. Lahman said. “She’s smart.”
Ms. Lahman said the woman each time reached for the purse on the back of the same chair — at a table by the door.
At the venerable Katz’s — the setting for the Meg Ryan scene in the 1989 comedy “When Harry Met Sally” that ended with a woman at another table saying “I’ll have what she’s having” — Alan Dell, one of the owners, said the deli had given the police tapes from its cameras. But he was unaware that the police were looking for help from the public until a reporter called.
He said he was off on the days the first two incidents took place. As for the most recent one, on Sept. 30, he said: “All I remember is someone lost a purse. We called the police. We gave them a tape.”
He said Katz’s had two guards on duty on weekends and one on weekdays, as well as an employee who issues the tickets used in ordering — “another pair of eyes that could help” if the woman were to return.

article_title: The Comptroller's Poster Problem
normalized_article_title: the comptroller's poster problem
text_content:
If for some bizarre reason you want your eyes to go out of focus, look up Section 10-119 of the city’s Administrative Code.
The Day
Clyde Haberman offers his take on the news.
You get the idea. The section rumbles on for another 355 words, leaving you googly-eyed well before the end. (You’ve got to love the part about the telegraph pole. Is there a crisis of telegraph-pole abuse in this city that we missed?)
But the point is plain: To use an old phrase, post no bills.
The warning is routinely violated. All sorts of material is taped to lampposts, whether by college students offering computer lessons or by families whose pets wander off. The Sanitation Department, which deals with these matters, isn’t in the habit of handing summonses to disconsolate cat owners. “We have a heart,” said Vito A. Turso, the chief department spokesman.
The municipal heart, however, does not go out to politicians who run afoul of Section 10-119 with their campaign posters. Election Day comes and goes. Winds blow. Rains fall. Posters become a sodden mess that slide to the ground. “Somebody’s got to sweep it up,” Mr. Turso said. That somebody is a sanitation worker. And so the department issues bushels of summonses to political campaigns, each ticket typically carrying a $75 fine.
This is not new. But the issue has resonance now because of questions raised about the city comptroller, John C. Liu, a man who would be mayor.
On Wednesday, Mr. Liu’s campaign finances were cast most unfavorably in an article in The New York Times that described a series of irregularities involving some of his donors. Interviewed by NY1 Wednesday night, he said that “to the extent that there are discrepancies, we are going to get to the bottom of it.”
Mr. Liu has another financial problem, though. The Sanitation Department says he owes the city more than $500,000, a result of 7,000 summonses for posters put up unlawfully when he ran for comptroller in 2009.
He is not alone in this regard. The previous comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., ran up more than $600,000 in sanitation fines in his 2009 race for mayor. The public advocate, Bill de Blasio, who is yet another would-be mayor, was good for $300,000 in tickets.
For the better part of two years, all three men refused to pay, challenging the validity of the fines. Two weeks ago, Mr. de Blasio finally agreed to settle. He didn’t need the “distraction,” he said. Presumably, he also didn’t need being repeatedly cast as a deadbeat in the tabloids.
But Messrs. Liu and Thompson have dug in their heels. Mr. Liu, in particular, often finds himself a leading character in a Daily News editorial feature called “Weasel Watch.”
The struggle over tickets is a pettifogger’s dream: Were summonses mailed to the correct campaign official? Was the postage right? Were the ticket numbers properly recorded?
There are also whispers within the Liu camp that City Hall may have had a hand in seeking substantial fines. Not that the mayor’s campaigns have been above putting up plenty of their own illegal posters. But they have a billionaire’s bank account to tap. For them, a $500,000 fine is pocket change, the cost of doing business.
For others, though, it’s real money. Small wonder, then, that they are latching onto every technicality in sight.
Still, squarely under the microscope as he now is, Mr. Liu may want to think how all this looks. Here he is, the city comptroller, a man whose job it is to wag his finger at others about keeping their books in order, and meanwhile his own finances are raising eyebrows.
Being a “Weasel Watch” regular is not something to brag about when running for mayor.
For more local news, including a campaign windfall for Republican politicians who supported same-sex marriage, the search for the missing cornerstone at St. Patrick’s Cathedral, a Bowery building that houses a flophouse and a luxurious hotel designed like a flophouse, see the N.Y./Region section.

A former New York Police Department detective testified that detectives frequently fabricated drug charges to meet arrest quotas. [Daily News] (Also see The New York Post.)
A $25 million lawsuit was filed in against the city in Brooklyn federal court by a girl who says she was kidnapped and forced into prostitution by an police detective when she was 13. [Brooklyn Daily Eagle]
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg told the Occupy Wall Street protesters that they would have to leave Zuccotti Park briefly so that it could be cleaned. [Wall Street Journal, New York Times] (Also see The Daily News, The New York Times and DNA Info.)
State education officials announced that New York City has to improve education standards for students who are learning English. [Wall Street Journal] (Also see The New York Times.)
Hundreds of teenagers crossed the Brooklyn Bridge to protest the Police Department’s stop-and-frisk policy. [Daily News] (Also see mcbrooklyn.)
A Staten Island man was arrested after he was captured on a surveillance video shooting a man who had spit in his wife’s face 12 times, the police said. [Daily News]
A 26-year-old man was arrested in connection with a groping attack in Sunset Park. He may be among those responsible for the series of attacks that have occurred in the park over the past few months. [Brooklyn Paper]
A second passenger died from injuries sustained in a helicopter crash in the East River last week. [New York Post] (Also see The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal.)
